PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: EVERINGHAM; JOHNSON; JONES; KERIN; MCMAHON; MORRIS; SCOTT
PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans- Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans- Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans- Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Everingham,Mr Les Johnson,Mr Charles Jones,Mr Kerin,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Morris and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The hotel industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places where the people may partake of the three basic needs of life: a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep.
2. The hotel industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia.
3. The hotel industry is almost entirely within the private sector and makes a large contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds.
4. The hotel industry has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment.
5. The hotel industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.
6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry's 5811 hotels in Australia.
7. The very steep rises in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian hotel industry.

8. Any further increases in excise on beer in the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community.
9. Such is its significance as a community requirement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its cost to the community would have an inflationary effect.
10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the hotel industry to pass on such increases to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

11. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence Fee taxes, which are directly linked to excise rates.
12. The hotel industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other tax imposts, its growth is at a standstill; and, inevitably must decline if beer excise is increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives:
(1) Recognise the importance and place of the Australian Hotel industry in the social and economic life of the nation.

(2) Accept that the viability of the hotel industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the hotel needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism.
And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Les McMahon and Mr Porter.

PETITION.TITLE: Rosemount Repatriation Hospital
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of undersigned Australian citizens showeth:

Rosemount Repatriation Hospital has been of inestimable value to eligible repatriation beneficiaries for many years, and the closure or dispersal of the facilities available at the hospital would be a retrograde step.

The proposed decision to close Rosemount Repatriation Hospital through active discouragement by departmental administrative officers of any further referrals by medical officers of patients for medically prescribed occupational therapy is objectionable.

Closure of Rosemount Repatriation Hospital would severely disadvantage veterans in Brisbane's northern suburbs, as well as their relatives and friends who would be required to travel a great distance in order to visit hospitalised veterans at either of the two alternative repatriation hospitals.
Closure of Rosemount Repatriation Hospital and transfer of patients to Greenslopes would greatly add to the administrative burden of that repatriation and general hospital.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will reverse its announced decision to close the Rosemount Repatriation Hospital.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That, as ex-servicemen are eligible to receive a Service Pension five years earlier than other Australian males are eligible to receive an age pension, subject to certain conditions, so too should the age at which the means test is applied to pension increases be reduced for service pensioners by five years to age 65.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will, in recognition of the service they have performed for their country, and because of reduced life expectancy as a result of that service, reduce the so-called means test free age limit for service pensioners from 70 years to 65.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy and Personal Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Paragraphs 107 and 108 of the Privacy and Personal Information discussion paper number 14, brought down by the Law Reform Commission in June 1980, undermines the family unit and the authority of parents, which is the Christian basis of our society, by proposing that ''between 12 and 16 years, a child should be entitled to object to disclosure of information to a parent.''
It is your petitioners sincere belief that:

(a) an adolescent between the ages of 12 and 16 is not at a mature enough stage of life to decide whether or not the disclosure of information to a parent will be in the best interests of the adolescent.
(b) as a record keeper has no responsibility for the child, and as his moral standards may be different to those of a parent, he should not be permitted to come between child and parent.

(c) a parent has a unique position which may enable him/her to perceive a situation that the record keeper does not. The parent must therefore be aware of the problem if remedial action is to be taken, and has the right to guide the child in the direction he/she feels fit.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Members of the House of Representatives will reject the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission and find some other means to protect children from the excessive abuse of some parents.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian House assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of children's services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 Budget. And further, that annual Budget allocations in the area of children's services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Refuges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action as it deems appropriate to ensure the continuing effectiveness of the Women's Refuge Program. In particular that:
1. Realistic funding levels be introduced to maintain existing services offered by women's refuges.
2. That the needs for child care in women's refuges be acknowledged by a specific and adequate allocation of funds for this purpose.
3. That funding be allocated for the purpose of assisting women and children to establish themselves in the community on leaving refuges.
4. That funding be allocated for refuges to address themselves to areas of special needs of migrant women in refuges.
5. That funding be made available for the establishment of new women's refuges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: El Salvador
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That sending financial aid to El Salvador identifies Australia with the repressive role of the security forces in that country.
That it increases the risk of wider military intervention.
That it jeopardises a constructive role Australia and the free world might play in the conflict.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Australian Government will undertake:
To desist from taking a course of action which can only contribute to the hardship and repression of the people of El Salvador.
To take a principled and public stand against the flagrant abuse of human rights in that country.
To consider instead, means of providing effective humanitarian assistance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Travelling Post Office Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembed. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the Australian Postal Commission's decision to phase out the Travelling Post Office (T.P.O.) in New South Wales.

The T.P.O. service has given the country people of New South Wales a reliable and efficient service for many years. To replace this service with a road system would be a backward step which we believe would result in long delays in mail going to and from country centres.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition to retain the T.P.O. service in New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discriminatory Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That the right to work without discrimination on any ground including, inter alia, discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex is a fundamental human right;

That it is both the duty and the responsibility of society to fully support those denied work and therefore those who are unemployed as a result of society's inability to provide full paid employment should be guaranteed an adequate income without discrimination on any ground, including inter alia discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate and adequate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, in employment of individuals under federal awards, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Women's Advisory Council
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
Their support for and endorsement of the National Women's Advisory Council.
We call on the Government to:
Continue to maintain the National Women's Advisory Council and increase Federal Government support for its activities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully petition:

That the government will act to prohibit the use of all public monies for the killing of unborn children. That the said use of government monies is an unacceptable government endorsement of a great national tragedy-the deaths annually of at least 80,000 unborn children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth: That we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will:
(1) Cease paying out taxpayers money for unlawful abortion procedures.
(2) Eliminate subsidies for abortion referral centres.
(3) Ensure that Australia's Human Rights Charter will include rights for unborn Australians primarily the right to life.
(4) Introduce further benefits for pregnant women to assist them in continuing with their pregnancy.
(5) Obtain each year from each of the State Attorneys General:
(a) written details as to the reasons for which procedures were carried out under item 6469 of the Medical Benefits Schedule,
(6) (b) Declaration that no procedures in respect of which a claim is made within the Health Insurance Act are unlawful abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Owing to an overwhelming and continuous demand by the Australian people for a cruise service within the economic scope of the working man and his family, we request the Government to lift the ban placed on Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels entering Australian Ports.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully calls for:
The immediate and unconditional withdrawal of any proposals to deny unemployment benefits to unemployed people under 18 years old.
That the level of benefits for all unemployed people, and including people receiving sickness benefits and pensions, be raised to at least 120 per cent of the poverty line.

That future employment policies be devoted to job creation and the restoration of full employment rather than the evasion of this responsibility by hiding the unemployed in short term training and education schemes.
Public acknowledgement of the fact that unemployment is the result of insufficient jobs and not the fault of any minority group, the education system or the unemployed themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled in the House of Representatives. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are gravely disturbed by the actions of militant unions and the ACTU, the failure of the President of the ACTU to assist positively in settling the dispute which has caused massive losses to Qantas our national airline, and we applaud the action of the Government in using RAAF planes to rescue Australians stranded abroad.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament and the Government should be of firm resolve not to permit such unions to hold the country to ransom and continue to take a forceful and resolute stand against such union militancy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
1. That we are gravely concerned at the lack of children's services within the city of Northcote.
2. That we are dismayed at the refusal of the Department of Social Security (Child Care Division) to fund a Family Day Care Programme within the city of Northcote.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will ensure adequate funds for children's services will be made available so that family day care may be provided within the city of Northcote.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Staging of American B52 Bombers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembed. The petition of the undersigned in the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
That the proposed use of Darwin Airport as a refuelling and rest and recreation base for American B52 bombers-

Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin and of all Australians, in that it establishes a stronger potential of Darwin being a nuclear target in any conflict between the U.S.A. and another power.
Impedes the sovereignty of the Australian nation in that Australian citizens would have neither control nor knowledge of whether B52s:
(a) carried nuclear weapons;
(b) were engaged in bombing missions against another State.
Violates the Australian people's independence and links this nation irreconcilably with United States foreign policies thereby destroying the potential for independent Australian defence policy.

Violates democratic procedures in committing the Australian nation to participation in future wars without due consultation and informed assessment by Australian citizens and further increases the militarisation of the Indian Ocean thereby increasing the likelihood of super power conflict in this region.
Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin, in that noise pollution and the threat of accidental radioactive fallout will increase substantially to the residents.
Negates the potential of the Australian nation to establish itself as a nation of peace in the Pacific region and violates Australia's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Members of the House of Representatives will ensure that the Prime Minister withdraw the offer of Darwin, or any other location in Australia, as a base or depot for American B52 bombers. And that furthermore will ensure that any request of such usage by the U.S. Government be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable members will be aware of the tragic reports this morning of the wounding of Pope John Paul II in St Peter's Square in Rome. All people throughout the world will be appalled by this senseless act of violence directed at one of the most dedicated advocates of peace and reconciliation. I inform the House that I have sent a message to the Pope in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I was deeply shocked and distressed to hear of the attempt on your life.
The Government and people of Australia join with me in wishing you a full and speedy recovery.
My Government deeply deplores such acts of violence which your Holiness has so strongly condemned.

Throughout his papacy John Paul has shown how one man can provide people with hope for the future. He has risen above the partisan divisions of society and, by his own example, has sought to bring people together to overcome the barriers of race and religion. It is tragic that in the world today there are people who seek to achieve their goals not through reason and example but through violence and murder. Their destructive acts do not advance their causes but breed horror and revulsion at those causes amongst the peoples of the world.

We thank God that the shocking act failed to achieve its purpose. However, it forces us to pause, to take stock and to ask ourselves why these senseless things happen and why it is that man's struggle for a better and more peaceful world is deflected through violence and terrorism. The concern, I think, is all the greater if some of the reports this morning that the would-be assassin was a known member of a terrorist gang are later proved correct. If that is so it means that the act has been perpetrated by design, deliberately, and that it was not the senseless act of one de- ranged man but the deliberate and concerted attempt of a terrorist group. If modern international terrorism is to embark on those paths, adding yet a further dimension to its horror, it means only that governments and peoples will have to reinforce their efforts against all terrorists and acts of terrorism.

Pope John Paul's life is a shining example of a commitment which seeks to uplift mankind. All Australians and all members of this House, I am certain, whatever their religion, will be greatly relieved to know that he will be able to continue his work, which is so important for his own church and the rest of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We heard the news of the attack on the Pope with horror. On behalf of the Australian Labor Party I am sending a message to Rome extending our best wishes for a comfortable recovery and for the early return of the Pope to his great task of leading the Catholic Church. Our concern will, I am sure, be reflected right across the Australian community. Pope John Paul II has never flinched in carrying out his duty. A man of great physical robustness and intellectual vigour, he has been a great voyaging Pope carrying a message of goodwill and peace throughout the world and a commitment to the oppressed of all nations of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Attacks of this kind are becoming increasingly incomprehensible. Sometimes they are the result of terrorism, which must be rejected utterly. So often, however, they seem to be the product of disturbed personalities seeking to work out tragedies in their personal lives by inflicting tragedy on others. We have seen assassination in the past but there seems now to be a new impetus to pointless violence which afflicts our society and which is extraordinarily difficult to contain. One of the problems in an open and free society such as the one in which we live is that prominent public figures must be accessible. But in being accessible, they are vulnerable; it is a strength and yet this brings in its wake a potential weakness as we see on this occasion and have seen on an earlier occasion in the United States of America. I repeat: The Opposition express its sympathy, its concern and its wish for a rapid and comfortable recovery for the Pope.
Honourable members-Hear, hear!

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PEACE-KEEPING FORCE IN THE MIDDLE EAST

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, arises out of certain answers given in this House yesterday relating to the negotiations for the commitment of Australian military forces to the Middle East. What is the basis of consideration for committing Australian military forces to the Middle East before the matter itself has even been considered or approved by the United Nations Security Council?

—As I am sure the Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows, under the terms of the Egypt-Israel peace treaty a United Nations peace-keeping force was to be established to supervise the final phase of Israel's withdrawal from the Sinai by the end of April 1982. There are indications that the establishment of such a force under United Nations auspices, as originally proposed, would be opposed by some Arab countries and probably the Soviet Union. Therefore, there could be major problems in reaching agreement within the United Nations framework for such a force. I understand that in these circumstances the parties immediately concerned-that is, the United States of America, Egypt and Israel-are giving consideration to a multinational force to do the job originally envisaged for the United Nations force. It is known, and we have known for some time, that Australia is under consideration for participation in such a force. I emphasise that no formal request has yet been made.
—Did we ask them to make one like we did in Vietnam?

—I emphasise: We have not asked that a request be made. We know we are under consideration, along with a number of other countries, to be asked about the possibility of establishing a multinational force. The matter rests there at the moment. I hope that the Opposition will join with the Government in working towards securing a peaceful settlement to the Middle East problem and in helping to progress the Camp David Accords.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Are the Government's present policies of sound economic management based on less interventionist government and a more market oriented economy creating enough jobs and creating them quickly enough to fulfil Australia's needs? Would a different economic policy create more jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can well appreciate the sentiments expressed in that question by the honourable member. Indeed, it should be well understood now by everyone that governments cannot create jobs; they can only adopt economic policies that will enable the economy itself to generate jobs of its own strength. That fact should be understood. That being so, it should also be said, of course, that the Government has a task and a responsibility to put in place programs which will give people the skills they need to be productive within the free economy. The Government has followed that broad objective and, indeed, its economic policies can clearly be seen to have been successful. We can see from the latest employment statistics that there have been very substantial increases in the number of people in jobs. Those increases have taken place in a broad range of industries. Again with respect to the unemployment figures, this month's statistics have made it plain beyond any doubt that there is a continuing drop in unemployment. Without going into the details, these figures show quite clearly that there have been falls in all age groups-both males and females-falls on the month, falls on the year and indeed the largest drop since this series of statistics was started. The Government wants these trends to continue but they will continue only if our economic policies which allow the economy to generate jobs are themselves allowed to continue.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked also about an alternative policy. I see that an alternative policy was espoused by the Leader of the Opposition in a recent address- last Friday night - to the Victorian Fabian Society. The policy advanced, which he and his party are now pursuing, is for more collectively owned goods and services. So, it should be plain without any doubt at all that the new forces in the Australian Labor Party, pampered to by the Leader of the Opposition, have adopted, on their own admission, this policy of collective ownership of goods and services. I have no doubt that, when the Australian people get an opportunity to say so, they will say that they do not want anything to do with the collective ownership of goods and services and will support the Government's economic policies which have improved the employment situation considerably.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communi- cations will be aware of the concern being expressed by regional television over two aspects of the proposed amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act. Will the Minister consider the following points made by regional television when finalising the amendments: Firstly, that the amendments will protect a television company from being stripped or irreparably damaged by a takeover which is subsequently disallowed by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal; and, secondly, the availability of supplementary licences and the timing of their introduction particularly taking into account the views of regional television on subscription television?

—The answer to the first part of the honourable member's question is yes. However, with regard to subscription television it is felt that it would be more appropriate for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to extend its cable television inquiry to take into account all aspects of subscription or pay television to ensure that when it is introduced into this country all the dimensions into which it can run are properly considered. Therefore, legislation introduced into this House in regard to supplementary licences is not intended to include any provision for subscription television. But a reference will be sent to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as an extension to what is now before the Tribunal so that, when considering cable television, it might also consider the parameters within which pay or subscription television should be introduced into Australia.

—I refer the Treasurer to the reported takeover bids by the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd for the Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd, by the National Bank of Australasia Ltd for the Commercial Banking Co. of Sydney Ltd and the possible takeover of the National Bank by the Bank of New South Wales, which takeover would be by far the largest in Australia's history. Is it a fact that the Government's decision to deregulate deposit interest rates last year and the subsequent rise in lending rates has meant large windfall profits for the banks as evidenced by the half-yearly profit increases of 33 per cent for the Bank of New South Wales, 39 per cent for the National Bank and 34 per cent for the ANZ Bank? Are the takeovers being financed out of these profits? Does the Treasurer regard it as proper that they should be paid for out of the pockets of Australian home buyers and small businessmen?

—Takeovers are normally financed out of profits. Equally, jobs are also normally provided out of profits. The idea that there is something inherently wrong or inherently grubby about companies making profits in Australia indicates just how out of touch people on the other side of the House are with economic reality in Australia at present and with the needs of the Australian community. The situation regarding bank mergers very simply is that proposals have been announced involving a merger of the ANZ Bank and the Commercial Bank of Australia on the one hand and a proposed merger of the National Bank and the Commercial Banking Co. of Sydney Ltd on the other. I have already indicated the attitude of the Government and the fact that a decision will be required when application is made for consent, if application is made for consent. The sort of considerations that will be taken into account have been the subject of a statement by me and answers to earlier questions in the House. I do not propose to speculate on Press comment regarding other possible arrangements. The only proposals which have been formally announced are the two that I have mentioned. So far as the profitability of the Australian banking system is concerned, the long term profit position of the system, if the honourable gentleman cares to analyse the statistics, does not lend support to the proposition that excessive or undue profits have been made.

—The Treasurer will recall that a fortnight ago he announced the termination of income tax indexation. Is it a fact that if the Government's promise of full tax indexation had been honoured the income tax bills of taxpayers would be $1,000m less than would apply in the absence of any income tax indexation? Is it also a fact that in the absence of any income tax indexation every one per cent increase in average income will cause a 1.4 per cent increase in income tax? As this will mean a clear reduction in real spending power for an average income earner, what steps does the Government have in mind to avoid what the Government was once fond of decrying-the secret tax of inflation?

—I have no specific reason to dispute the figures that were used by the honourable member for Banks. Let me make it quite plain that, as everybody in this House will know, this Government was elected in October 1980 on the basis of a policy and a platform put forward at that election and that policy and that platform contained a commitment to a tax cut of some $500m which would take effect on 1 July this year as a consequence of the operation during that financial year of half tax indexation. As I made plain in my statement of two weeks ago, that commitment will be met in full without deduction, without quibble and without any equivocation. Any suggestion that the Government will do other than honour in full what it said in the last election campaign about the provision of that tax concession is complete nonsense and totally incorrect. As to the situation after the next financial year regarding taxation adjustments, I also made clear in my statement of a couple of weeks ago that in future the Government will make tax adjustments on a discretionary basis, normally in the Budget context. That remains and will remain our position.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: SHORTER WORKING WEEK

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: What is the Government's position on recently announced New South Wales legislative changes facilitating a shorter working week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the position that appears to have been adopted by the New South Wales Government is regrettable from a number of points of view. It is regrettable because it would seem to indicate to the New South Wales industrial commissions that they should ignore and indeed almost seek to overturn the decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in relation to productivity bargaining. Against the background of the decisions of the Arbitration Commission which have been handed down after full debate and after the parties had put their various points of view, it would seem to be quite arbitrary and unreasonable. It would seem to be offering a direction to the New South Wales industrial commissions which is entirely of a political nature. Certainly it will be very unfortunate for industry in New South Wales. It is very similar to the legislation which Mr Wran introduced some time ago in relation to a reduction in working hours in the power industry, which spearheaded a general movement downwards in hours throughout the power industry in Australia. Again I find it difficult to understand how a Premier of a State which is so dependent upon industrialisation and heavy industry can undertake moves which must undermine the profitability of that industry and, therefore, undermine the capacity of that industry to employ people in New South Wales.
—Sabotaging Australia.

—My colleague interjects that he is sabotaging Australia. He certainly is sabotaging the efforts of this Government and of other people to encourage greater employment. If there is a choice as to which State industries will go to-New South Wales or another State-as a result of this kind of action they certainly will be looking to some other State. What the New South Wales Government is doing is unfortunate from another point of view. At the recent Premiers Conference, on the initiative of Sir Charles Court, we examined the need for an inquiry into the impact of a 35-hour week on the Australian economy and whether there should be a broad based examination of the role of wages in the community, how to achieve non-inflationary growth, and the impact of hours on the general well-being and living standards of Australian families. There was broad acceptance of some terms of reference that were initiated by the Commonwealth but worked over by State officials. It has now been left to see who would be able to undertake that inquiry, in a sense not just on behalf of the Commonwealth Government but, it was hoped, on behalf of all the State governments. The Premier of Tasmania in particular was keen to see a bipartisan approach to these issues. The decision of the New South Wales Government seems to be pre-empting that examination in a way which again is entirely unfortunate. If Mr Wran has not entered into commitments with the trade unions which he finds have put him in shackles on this issue, I urge him to reconsider this decision to see whether he cannot follow Mr Lowe's example.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will remain silent.
—Don't be put off because everyone is going to sleep, Malcolm.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will remain silent.
—Turn the record over Mal. Away you go again.

—Order! The honourable member for Newcastle will cease interjecting. The Prime Minister is entitled to cease speaking while there is continual interjection. I ask honourable members to remember the dignity of the House and to remain silent.

—I urge the Premier of New South Wales to follow the example of the Premier of Tasmania in this matter and to join with the Commonwealth and other States in seeking a proper, impartial examination of these grave and serious issues which go to the living standards and the wellbeing of Australians and Australian families no matter what State they come from. Therefore, I urge him to desist from this legislation until the examination which was discussed at the recent Premiers Conference can be initiated and pursued and the results examined by the Government.

—Does the Minister for Health recall telling me, in answer to Question No. 235 on 24 February this year, that the proportion of private patients in public hospitals already paying for accommodation varied from 53 per cent in New South Wales to 20 per cent in Queensland and 14 per cent in Tasmania? I ask: Is it, therefore, not true that the introduction of a means test will produce a much larger increase in hospital income in Queensland and Tasmania, assuming a fairly even living standard across Australia? How can he then say that Queensland is entitled to extra money for hospitals and New South Wales is not?

—I do not recall my exact answer that I gave in February, I think it was, of this year to the question asked by the honourable gentleman. My recollection is that the figures at the present time for New South Wales are, as the honourable member stated, overstated. I believe that the number of pay-bed patients in New South Wales is less than 53 per cent at the present time.
—It is still much more than Queensland.

—It is certainly still much more than Queensland. The honourable gentleman mentioned Queensland. As I said in this House yesterday, the Government looked at the special position of Queensland after listening to arguments put both at the Premiers Conference and at the meeting of Health Ministers last Friday. In line with the recommendations contained in the report of the Jamison Committee of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, particularly that recommendation that suggested that too rapid changes would be disruptive in any hospital system, the Cabinet has made a decision that a once only adjustment should be made in the case of Queensland. In the case of Tasmania, we still have not received a reply in relation to whether it will continue the fifty-fifty cost sharing arrangement which, of course, it is at liberty to do until 1985.

—My question to the Prime Minister concerns the proposed children's foundation mentioned in the Prime Minister's policy speech last year. Is it the intention of the Government to proceed with this proposal in the near future? If so, will the views of voluntary agencies, such as the Children's Protection Society and the Mission of St James and St John, be taken into account before deciding the nature and constitution of the foundation? Would the Prime Minister agree--
—What about the Melbourne City Mission?

—I include the Melbourne City Mission, which the honourable member for Melbourne knows very well. Does the Prime Minister agree that such a foundation should highlight problems of child abuse through community education programs and sponsor research into the neglect and maltreatment of children on a national level?

—There is good reason to believe that the problem of child abuse is much more widespread in the community than many people understand or would readily be prepared to believe. The Government is proceeding with this election policy commitment. My colleague the Minister for Social Security has been having discussions with the States. Obviously, the attitude of voluntary agencies will need to be taken into account in determining the final form of the foundation. I think it ought to be said that the idea of establishing a national body of this kind came from voluntary agencies themselves and from people who have been intimately and very closely associated with the problem of child abuse, especially in New South Wales, including the Sydney area. Research and community education are two of the things in which such a foundation would certainly involve itself. The foundation would be seeking to work with and through voluntary agencies to a very large extent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Firstly, will he confirm that he is to receive an honorary doctorate when he visits the United States of America on a two-week tour during the winter recess? Secondly, will the decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions to introduce tuition fees for university and college of advanced education students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to the attainment of initial tertiary qualifications mean that for many students the receipt of honorary doctorates in overseas countries is now their best or only prospect of obtaining higher tertiary qualifications?

QUESTION.PARA: Government supporters interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not like that part. Thirdly, will the Prime Minister inform this House and the one-third of a million concerned tertiary education students in this country whether the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions firstly, to introduce a loans scheme as a supplement to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme; secondly, to adjust downwards the rate of TEAS to take account of the availability of loans through this scheme; and thirdly, to tighten further eligibility guidelines for TEAS, are attempts to pave the way for complete reintroduction of tertiary fees for all students? Fourthly, what effect will the inevitable--
—Order! The honourable lady has asked enough questions for the moment. I call on the Prime Minister to answer them.

—The answer to the friendly part of the honourable member's question is yes. The answer to the other parts of the honourable member's question is that, if the Government's policy has been adequately understood, it is quite clear that there are no fees in relation to primary degrees.

—Did the Minister for Primary Industry attend a meeting in Canberra yesterday with representatives of the wool industry on the proposed sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority? If so, can he say what the outcome of the meeting was? In particular, has the industry persuaded the Government to change its decision on the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority? If not, what assurances was the Government able to give the industry to calm its fears about the Australian Wool Testing Authority becoming a private enterprise body?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the first part of the honourable member's question, along with the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry and Commerce yesterday I met representatives of the wool industry to discuss the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority. The answer to the second part of the question is no; the industry did not put forward any reasons that would convince us that we should not sell it. I think that the interesting thing is that, in all the many telegrams and telexes that I have received from across Australia from wool growing interests on this matter, until yesterday nobody had really sought from me what proposals we had in respect of the sale.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps I can inform the House that it has never been the intention, and it was not the intention when the decision was taken, simply to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority to the highest bidder and to have it broken up so that it lost its proper function in the issuing of certificates on wool testing. Indeed it is proposed that the industry itself can devise the form that the new structure will take. The industry will decide the representation that will manage it and, along with the Australian Wool Corporation, it will handle future wool testing. That body will be set up either as a wool testing house or as a foundation of some type with an absolute assurance that any certificate issued will be a legal certificate in a similar fashion to the one presently issued. I think that, following the discussions, those representatives of the industry who were present were certainly much more settled in their approach to this matter. The wool industry ought to know that the first interest we have in respect of the sale of the Wool Testing Authority is to ensure that there is no disruption to wool sales and the procedures that follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction and concerns the pressure for an increase in interest rates that will accompany the Government's restrictive monetary policy response to a large capital inflow in recent months. Does the Minister agree that a one per cent rise in housing loan interest rates from 11 1/2 per cent to 12 1/2 per cent will impose an additional monthly repayment burden of $22 on a $30,000 loan and would increase the deposit gap for new home buyers? What provision is the Government prepared to make in order to prevent hardship to low and middle income earners seeking to buy homes or attempting to pay off housing loans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Sydney has raised several interesting questions. The facts and figures that he has quoted are, from memory, near enough to accurate, but I remind him to look at some of the statistics on the availability of housing finance in Australia.
—Why don't you draw up a chair, Tom?

—It is a very serious matter. The Government is interested in maximising home ownership for all Australians. The most recent statistics indicate that the number of loans made available in Australia in the last 12 months to December 1980 totalled 240,345. That is an all-time record for Australia. We have one of the highest levels of home ownership in the world-71.9 per cent of Australian families own their own homes. The honourable member raised the matter of a deposit gap. One can readily understand the difficulty of a person saving for a deposit. However, let us analyse the facts. Only 30 per cent of the Australian home buyers are single income families. So 70 per cent of the people purchasing homes are from two-income families. Obviously it is easier for two-income families to save a deposit for a home. It must also be remembered that if finance is to be made available to home purchasers it is necessary not to isolate funds for home ownership. I fully support the initiatives announced by the Treasurer in this Parliament at the end of last year. They had the net result of attracting such funds to home ownership as to enable the totality of funds allocated last year to be a record.
—They can't afford to pay it back.

—The honourable member said that they cannot afford to pay it back. The statistics speak for themselves. The honourable member for Sydney quoted certain facts relative to a $30,000 loan. For the information of honourable members opposite, the facts are that in December 1978 it took 27.1 per cent of average weekly earnings to pay back interest and redemption on a $30,000 savings bank loan over 25 years. In December 1980 it took only 26.1 per cent. These facts and figures are indicative of the climate of stability created by this Government since 1975. I will conclude on this note-

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously those who sit opposite are not interested in the important matter raised by the honourable member for Sydney. Later today I will be introducing legislation concerning the new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. In that agreement initiatives will be developed, but the prime responsibility for welfare housing in Australia belongs to the State governments. I only hope that the New South Wales Government will show a little bit of concern for the underprivileged and will not go on uttering a litany of deceit in this vital and important matter.
—Is the Treasurer aware of factors in the administration of governments in Australia which lend support to the decisions of the committee which reviewed Commonwealth functions?

—One of the more interesting responses to the statements made by the Prime Minister arising out of the review of Commonwealth functions is the claim that it was an unnecessary exercise in pruning the size of government and an unnecessary exercise in trying to attain greater efficiency in the operation of government and the operation of the Public Service. Some light is thrown on the validity of that criticism by reports this morning of very great concern being expressed about the waste of money in the administration of government in New South Wales arising out of a parliamentary committee chaired by the Australian Labor Party member for Heffron, Mr Brereton, which indicates that millions of dollars have been wasted in the administration of government in New South Wales. Apparently the New South Wales Government has $3m of the taxpayers' money to spend on funding political campaigns but it is not sufficiently concerned about the administration of government.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. We are concerned about the affairs of the Commonwealth Government. Today three attacks have been made in this Parliament against the New South Wales Government by honourable members opposite. They have been fallacious attacks.
—The Treasurer is being relevant to the question.

—I think this morning's reports are further evidence of the need for all governments, whether they be the Commonwealth Government or any of the governments of the Australian States, to examine their own efficiencies and look at the sizes of their administrations and their public services. In this respect it would be a very good thing if the New South Wales Government followed the lead not only of the Commonwealth Government but also of the Victorian, Western Australian and South Australian governments which have very much decided in recent weeks to duplicate what we have done.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether he recalls saying in the House on 3 December 1976:

QUESTION.PARA: If these developmental proposals are to work it will require the kind of co-operation that comes from people of our political philosophy; the sort of co-operation that one finds from Sir Charles Court or Mr Hamer . . .

In view of this comment and his repeated pledges that Commonwealth-State relations under the Fraser Government would be established 'through a process of genuine consultation and co-operation', I also ask the Prime Minister whether he will say what has happened to these good intentions, leading to Sir Charles Court stating in a letter to him, and anyone else who was faintly interested, on 8 May:

I resent the States being treated as though they were merely departments of the Commonwealth Government to be told how to manage their affairs and forced to accept whatever arrangements your Government considers appropriate to your own budgetary requirements.

Sir Charles further complained about the Government's policies in relation to the States being an 'imposition of your Government's proposals on the States without prior advice or discussion and against their unanimous opposition'. In fact, is this nasty confrontation with States further evidence of the Prime Minister's manic determination with getting his own way?

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is evidence of anything it is evidence of our determination to protect the taxpayer's dollars. It is the taxpayers who have the prime right to those dollars and to the expenditure of those dollars. It is time that all governments in Australia showed a concern for that and an interest in that. I have no doubt that a greater number of people right throughout the community will come to see that it is the Commonwealth Government above all that is protecting the taxpayers of this nation from higher and higher taxes.

—Can the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the House whether any challenges have been lodged in respect of the regularity of recent elections of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union?

—I thank the honourable member for Dundas for his question because I am sure that all honourable members would be very interested to know that in fact challenges have been made to that election. Challenges have been lodged with the Industrial Registrar, who has referred to the Industrial Relations Bureau the application by two members of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union so that the Bureau may inquire into the circumstances surrounding that election and report to the Industrial Registrar. The applications have been made with respect to the AMWSU National President, Mr Dick Scott, the Assistant National Secretary, Mr Laurie Carmichael, and the National Organiser for Division 2, Mr. W. Martin. Of course, this is a very serious matter because the AMWSU is the largest union in Australia. It happens also to be the union which is mounting such a serious campaign against industry in Australia at the moment through the 35-hour week. Therefore while one, of course, cannot pre-empt the inquiry to be made by the Industrial Relations Bureau or, if the matter should be taken to the court, the findings of that court, having regard to the position of the AMWSU in the union movement in Australia, it is a matter of great concern to find that two members of that union have considered it serious enough to bring the matter to the attention of the Industrial Registrar and for him to refer the matter to the Industrial Relations Bureau.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. With the close-down of the Commonwealth Employment Service data collection unit, will the Australian Bureau of Statistics alter its information base to include such relevant details as the number of people registered for work, the age categories, and unemployment through part time work only being available?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the honourable member for Scullin has raised this matter because it gives me an opportunity to make some comments to the House with respect to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. The specific answer to the honourable member's question is that I will look at the proposed changes he has suggested to see what precise details are already collected in those areas and whether improvements, if any, can be made. Implicit in the question, and in some of the other comments that have been made over the last few days, is a suggestion that the termination of the Commonwealth Employment Service statistics is in some way a reprehensible act of the Government.
—It is.

—I notice that already that expression of opinion has been confirmed by a number of members on the Opposition front bench. May I say two things about this matter. It should be well known and accepted by anyone who understands the statistics and their method of collection that the CES statistics cannot properly be regarded as an acceptable form of statistics if one wants to know the true extent and the details of both employment and unemployment in Australia. In the first place, it is known that there is no need for a person to be unemployed before he or she may register with the CES. Secondly, there is at least some double counting amongst registrations at the CES, and in a number of cases people who obtain employment through the valuable services of the CES do not have themselves removed from the roll.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government in reaching its decision was influenced by a number of things. It was influenced by the fact that both the Hancock report and the Norgard report drew attention to deficiencies in the CES statistics and, indeed, the Norgard report went so far as to say that the CES figures should not be used.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the regions? Tell us about that.

—I have been influenced in considering the debate and the argument on this matter by an additional set of factors, and this is particularly relevant in view of the comments made by way of interjection by a number of members on the Opposition front bench.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the years a number of prominent members of the Australian Labor Party have drawn attention to the deficiencies in the CES figures and have maintained on those occasions that the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures are the most reliable set of statistics and should be used. Might I remind the Leader of the Opposition of his remark in a debate in this place. After discussing this issue, he said: 'But the Bureau's statistics are more reliable.' I suggest that the honourable member who asked the question and those who have views similar to his should take up this matter in debate with the Leader of the Opposition. If the Bureau's statistics are more reliable, then those statistics should be used and not the figures-one cannot call them more than that-collected by the CES, which is not a statistics collection agency. Without unduly taking the time of the House, I ask leave to incorporate in Hansard a number of statements by prominent members of the Opposition, both present and when in government between 1972 and 1975, which highlight the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Point of order--
—The Minister has asked leave to incorporate documents in Hansard. So far he has not identified what is to be incorporated.

—I wish to incorporate a number of statements by the former Minister for Labor and Immigration, Mr Cameron, the former Minister for Housing, Mr Riordan, the present member for Adelaide, two statements by the present member for Gellibrand, and a statement by the present Leader of the Opposition--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Which highlight the superiority of the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures.
—The Minister will cease speaking. The Minister has identified that which he wishes to incorporate. Is leave granted?

—Mr Speaker, I have raised a point of order. I would first like to be assured that the references are more reliable and relevant than the Minister claimed in terms of what he said a little earlier about a comment I was supposed to have made in this Parliament. I certainly did, as I recall it in relation to seasonally adjusted unemployment figures which the Government suppressed because they were embarrassing the Government--
—The honourable gentleman is not taking a point of order; he is arguing the issue.
—There were no unemployment surveys--
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—Well, it is a matter of credibility, if not integrity, and in those circumstances we would have to oppose a doctored document coming forward.
—Leave is not granted. I call the Minister.

—I am certainly not going to read out all the documents because we would be here all day; I will table them. In conclusion, I will read to the House one of the statements which I think is particularly appropriate. Mr Riordan, a former Minister for Housing, said:

ANSWER.PARA: It is no use honourable gentlemen opposite trying to quibble about it. The fact is that the Bureau of Statistics conducts a survey consistent with international standards.
I table those extracts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. This is highly irrelevant and thoroughly misleading.
—I know honourable members opposite would have difficulty understanding the simple issue of integrity--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—The facts are that there were no--
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. There is far too much noise on my right. I ask honourable members on my right to remain silent. I call the Leader of the Opposition.
—These quotes referred to seasonally adjusted unemployment figures which we wish were still being published and which have been suppressed by this Government.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order.
—I am hearing a point of order.
—This is clearly--
—The Leader of the Opposition is arguing the issue.
—It is clearly a display of mendacity from the new Minister to show that he belongs to the Fraser Government. He has the right qualities, a lack of integrity--
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition is aware that he has used unparliamentary expressions. I ask him to withdraw.
—Mr Speaker, it is a very dishonest display by the Minister.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw.
—Yes, but for gosh sake do we have to sit here and bear with--
—Yes.
—I know that the Minister for Communications would expect it. We know how he made his family fortune.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—Order! Honourable members on my right will remain silent. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw.
—Mr Speaker, I have and I repeat it.
—If the honourable member has withdrawn, I ask him to resume his seat and not to interject continually.
-For the information of honourable members I present the Department of Education report for 1980.

—Pursuant to section 7 of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Act 1976, I present report 4, which is the second report in relation to the relationships reference for the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations, entitled 'The Provision of Roads: A Report on the Relationships Among the Three Spheres of Government in Australia'.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

—The honourable member for O'Connor has indicated to me that he wishes to make a personal explanation. Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr TUCKEY

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night during the adjournment debate the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) included a statement in his presentation on behalf of the Women Against Rape organisation. The statement was in reply to my speech supporting the sale of strata title sections to the present tenants of the Belconnen Mall. The honourable member for Fraser said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I was interested in the honourable member for O'Connor who has apparently become an instant expert on the Belconnen Mall. I wonder whether it is a fact or whether he was merely reading a speech prepared for him by the Minister for the Capital Territory.

That statement is totally inaccurate. —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.

—He may proceed.

—On page 9 of today's Australian newspaper, there is a report of a rally which took place outside Parliament House yesterday. I said it was probably because of the second rate antipodean education of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that he is so disparaging of Australia's education system.

—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

—Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a point of order. The honourable member for Franklin, in claiming to have been misrep- resented, was deliberately using this House for publicity purposes, seeking to spread the fact that he is having a birthday today. We have all accepted his invitation and we will see him at the bar later.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

—I have been informed that, in the adjournment debate last night, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) made a number of comments reflecting upon myself, the Australian Federal Police and the Returned Services League. Unfortunately I did not have the traditional courtesy of being forewarned--
—I interrupt the honourable gentleman to advise him that he cannot make a personal explanation on behalf of the Returned Services League or anybody else, just himself.

—I appreciate that, sir. The RSL will take care of itself.
