DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITMENT OF AUSTRALIAN FORCES IN THE MIDDLE EAST

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to move for the suspension of Standing Orders. Accordingly, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Foreign Affairs from forthwith (1) making a statement to the House giving details of all negotiations with the United States in relation to the commitment of Australian military forces in the Middle East and (2) tabling all relevant documents.

Yesterday and today the House was advised that the Government had entered into negotiations, by way of correspondence, for the commitment of Australian military forces in the Middle East. I want to make it very clear that the Australian nation should at least have this matter discussed in this Parliament. We do not want any smuggling in of Australian forces to occur. We do not want any deceit and deception of the Australian nation to occur.

In answers to the questions which have already been asked on this matter it has been indicated that perhaps the Government is acting in the spirit of and in accordance with what is known as the Camp David Accords. Let me make it very clear and place on record that the Camp David Accords, at all levels, at all times and in all sections, place the observance of the Accords and the treaty in fulfilment of it in the hands of the United Nations Security Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman is arguing the merit of the case he would be arguing if the Standing Orders were suspended. He must confine himself to why the Standing Orders should be suspended.

—I appreciate the point, Mr Speaker. The point I am trying to make in furtherance of what you have said is that the Parliament has been led to believe that what is being done by the Government is in accordance with the Accords. I am trying to make the point that it is not. The serious step of moving for the suspension of the Standing Orders is being taken so that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) can clearly indicate that the action taken by the Government is in accordance with what has already been agreed between two parties which were engaged in war. It is a matter of the utmost significance. In urging the Minister to make a statement, I point out that there is confusion in the Government ranks. I have evidence that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) has said that Australia would always have its forces under the umbrella of the United Nations.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, in answer to a question, the Minister for Foreign Affairs made the point that perhaps we could not get United Nations approval and, therefore, there had to be negotiations between the United States and this Government as to what type of force ought to be committed to the Sinai Desert or the Middle East. No Australian force should be committed there until such time as we have had a full debate on this issue in this Parliament and obtained the approval of the Parliament and the approval of the Australian people. Any suggestion that the commitment is in accordance with the Camp David Accords is incorrect. The suggestion was made today that it is in accordance with the treaty that apparently was approved subsequent to the Camp David Accords. That is not correct.

I draw attention to the fact that what the Parliament has already been told is quite erroneous and quite misleading. For example, the treaty says that the parties shall request that United Nations forces be deployed. Annex one of the treaty says that the parties shall agree on the nations from which the United Nations forces and observers will be drawn. Annex one contains an express prohibition in the statement that the parties will accept or support a United States proposal concerning the composition of the United Nations force. A further prohibition is the statement that the force will be drawn from nations other than those which are permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. The United States is a member of the United Nations Security Council and, therefore, cannot participate in that force.

It is for those reasons that we stress that the Minister should make a statement urgently. Clearly it must be made in accordance with what has already been agreed to between the parties concerned. If any force is to be committed to the area-I stress that this Parliament must first agree on that-it would only be a force approved by the United Nations and, secondly, it would only be a United Nations force. The Government appears, by deceit and certainly by some secret method, to have had discussions by correspondence with General Haig or somebody else on the basis that we might be part of a United States joint force in the Sinai, which is contrary to all the arrangements made in accordance with the Camp David Accords, the peace treaty itself and the United Nations' prior commitments in the area. The proposed settlement relates to the Sinai. It was the subject of a resolution of the United Nations known as Resolution 242. Resolution 242 provided for the withdrawal of military forces. It went on to say that the Secretary-General of the United Nations would designate a special representative to proceed to the Middle East to establish and maintain contacts with the states concerned in order to promote agreement and assist efforts to achieve a peaceful and accepted settlement and that the Secretary-General would expect a report on the progress of the efforts of the special representative.

So there we have a commitment from 1967 onwards for the United Nations Security Council to be directly involved. In fact as a result of that Resolution, and the suggestion that all forces should withdraw, there followed some sort of settlement on the basis that the UN would be monitoring the whole situation. This is a matter of the utmost urgency to the nation. It is a matter that could well involve us in another Vietnam with all the problems that arose there.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Parliament is in recess next week.

—We do not want to have a situation-as my honourable friend has suggested-where the Government could make a decision while this Parliament is in recess and we would be unable to evaluate the situation. Yesterday, in answer to a question the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said that the Parliament would be advised when a decision had been taken. That is far too late for us. I wish to make it clear that at present no forces are to be committed anywhere unless firstly, this Parliament debates the matter, and, secondly, the Australian nation approves. At this stage there is not one tittle of evidence which would justify a commitment of Australian forces to the Middle East. It could be done only if the Australian nation approved and it would have to be a United Nations force.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome a debate on this matter. At present we are in a situation where all we have learned, as a result of our own questioning, is that the Government is considering making a decision. We know that the Minister has corresponded with the American Secretary of State, General Haig. We do not know what that correspondence contains but the Press seems to know some of the elements of it. Certainly, that correspondence is some weeks, if not some months, old. It is important that we have a discussion in this Parliament. It is important for decisions to be made in accordance with the international standards of peace and security. It is quite wrong for Australia to be involved in any United States force. During the Camp David Accords there were definite discussions about the sorts of facilities that could be taken over in the Sinai; for example, the use of the air fields near El Arish and other places. It is said that this has to be in accordance with the Accords and that the facilities will have to be used for civilian purposes only. Imagine our forces being committed to this area, with other forces of a military nature, and with all these air bases and other facilities available. Is it not likely that other nations nearby-this can include super-powers-would say that the use of the facilities would be an act of hostility?

Are we to shut our eyes to the fact that in 1973, Dr Kissinger, when leading United States foreign policy, was anxious to have a rapid deployment force in the Middle East on the basis that there could be immediate strike potential so that the United States could take immediate military action to protect its oil supplies? At that time the then Labor Government said that no such action should be approved. The French Government said the same thing but the impetus was coming from Dr Kissinger and the hawks in Washington as far back as 1973. The same thing can happen again because the same influences seem to be there. If, as the Washington Post says, this is a back door method of smuggling forces--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman is now arguing the issue.

—I just want to stress that this is a matter of urgency. There is a precedent for deception-over Vietnam. We were lucky to have a Labor Government which decried it and denied it. On this occasion it appears that correspondence has already been entered into on the basis that something will be done. Mr Speaker, I think you will agree that the people of this nation are entitled to know why there is a need for such a commitment. If there is to be a commitment it must be in the interests of peace. That immediately excludes the United States from the point of view of the Accords. This is important when one looks at our multicultural nation because the people in Australia come from all those areas and they have all sorts of different political points of view.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude on this note: If one looks at the reaction to the Camp David Accords, one sees complete hostility from Syria, Libya and certainly from the Palestinian Liberation Front. One sees it also from Saudi Arabia and Jordon. If we look at those countries, if we look at our nation, and at the sort of people who would be suggesting that this is the forerunner of a major flashpoint in the Middle East, and a war in which we would be involved, would our troops be safe? Would they be contributing towards peace? I would suggest not. It is about time that this Government made a statement forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. It is a procedural move which is necessary if we are to have any opportunity at all-of course, the motion has to be successful to get that opportunity-to discuss a matter which is assuming increasingly grave implications for Australia. The House will rise tonight and adjourn for a week. In the meantime, there may be profound developments in relation to this matter and the Parliament will not have had the opportunity to apply its attention to those developments, to explore the implications and to ask questions very properly about why, on the basis of the evidence before us on this point, there has been a dramatic change of heart on the part of government in relation to the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us understand clearly what this proposal is. It is not a proposal for an independent, impartial, international peace-keeping force. It is a proposal for a United States sponsored on-the-ground military strategic force to be set up in the Middle East. The Washington Post has said it as bluntly as that. In those circumstances, we wish to create the opportunity for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) to make a considered statement to the Parliament on this matter and, I hope, to allow debate to proceed.

Let us look at some of the features of this matter. There is a fundamental conflict associated with the unfolding of the Government's attitude on the proposal that there should be a US sponsored and controlled military force on the ground in the Middle East. It is becoming inreasingly clear from statements from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that, in fact, the Government is increasingly attracted to this proposal. I am grateful to the Melbourne Sun-not for many things-for its article on the front page this morning. I quote it exactly. It reminds us:
On March 17 Mr Anthony told the Egyptian Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Mr Ghali, that Australia would not be involved--
He said that Australia would not be involved-
in any force the United Nations was not party to.

That is the fundamental attitude of the Government as expressed by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) speaking for this country overseas. He said that we would not be involved with any force unless it was a United Nations force. The article continued:
At the time, Mr Anthony told journalists that any move outside the UN would be 'illegal'.
The article went on to state:
Such a move would be similar to Russia moving into Poland on the basis that it had been 'invited', Mr Anthony said.

I concur entirely with those sentiments. But I inquire why there has been this dramatic change. I come to the next point. There are elements associated with this that have a deadening familiarity about them, a depressing deja vu, as it were. Let us take Vietnam. We know, because of documentation that has been revealed to the public, that rather than the Americans being unrestrained in their enthusiasm to rush into an escalation of the conflict in Vietnam, they were incited, they were bulldozed, by representatives of a conservative government of the same colour as this one, a government of which the Prime Minister was a member.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition will return to discuss the issue as to why the Standing Orders should be suspended to allow a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—If that is not a good reason, Mr Speaker, let me put this proposition. I thank you for your indulgence. We are concerned that Australia may well end up in a situation which has depressing similarities to that which we endured in the 1960s. We were taken into a conflict which forever will blight the reputation and the credibility of conservative government on this sort of matter. That is what we want to discuss. That is a grave matter. We have seen on a smaller scale, but no less significant, the way in which the Government wanted to establish home porting facilities in Western Australia for new US strategic forces thus converting Fremantle and Perth into a prime nuclear target. We have seen the Government's attitude on the B52 bombers and the way it wanted to go into an Indian Ocean naval exercise with America before the election and then rushed out after the election because it understood the foreign policy and trade implications.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to be involved in anything, we want to be in control of it. We will not be in control of events in the Middle East should we participate in this sort of proposal with it being controlled by the United States. Decisions could be taken and forces put in train over which we have no control. I reassert the fundamental principle that we will stand by and fight for unflinchingly, that is, to preserve the sovereignty of this country and to preserve the lives of Australian military personnel. While we are not opposed to an adequately set up UN commitment we will oppose this tooth and nail.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes. Reference was made to me. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) quoted a report of my visit to Egypt. I would like him to table the authority for that quotation.
—I quoted the source. I am happy to table it if you wish.
—You did not quote the source. What is the source?
—I told you. It is this morning's Sun, quoting you from its record.
—Who was the author? Is it in quotes?
—Have it incorporated in Hansard.
—You see, he says things and he doesn't remember that he said them.

—The Leader of the Opposition will remain silent. The Deputy Prime Minister, by my indulgence, asked a question of the Leader of the Opposition requesting him to provide information. Is the Leader of the Opposition in a position to do so?

—Yes. I quoted the source when I was speaking. It is this morning's Melbourne Sun. It is an article by Trevor Hawkins. There are a number of quotations in quote marks attributed to the Deputy Prime Minister. I have read the article in full. It is in the record. If the Deputy Prime Minister wishes I am happy to have it incorporated in Hansard. I think this is unnecessary. I think the problem is that the right honourable member is one who makes a speech without knowing what he will say and then sits down wondering what he did say.
—The Leader of the Opposition has no need to make a comment of that kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion for the suspension of Standing Orders contains two items. The second one relates to a prohibition within Standing Orders of which, I am sure, no honourable member of this House would be aware. It is quite appropriate that at any time a Minister is able to table any document in the House. Therefore, there is no need to suspend Standing Orders for that purpose. Of course, whether the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) wishes to table the documents is another matter. I suggest that there is no obligation at all on him to table the documents. I indicate to the House that I suspect he would not wish to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The first part of the motion is also, I think, of some interest. I am really delighted to see honourable members of the Opposition supporting this motion this morning. As you know, Mr Speaker, part of today is set aside for General Business. It is General Business, Thursday No. 2. We have a Notice Paper that is issued in this Parliament which covers the proceedings of this House each day. This sets down the business which will be conducted. A day for the discussion of General Business is a day for private members, that is, not the members of the front bench, not the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) who has moved a motion for the suspension of the Standing Orders or the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) who seconded the motion. It is not a time when members of the front bench of the Opposition any more than members of the front bench of the Government get up to take the time of private members. It is a time when properly business of the House is laid down and the private members in this place have an opportunity to conduct matters.

I think it is also of interest that there are two matters that are specifically limited. Time is available under our Standing Orders until 12.45 p.m. so that there can be an adequate discussion of those matters. The first matter is a proposed motion listed by Mr Barry Jones and the second by Mr Holding-both of those honourable gentlemen are, of course, members of the Opposition. It is interesting that they are, in other words, matters that the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition are prepared to push aside in order that debate can continue on this matter. I think it is also worth saying that not only are those two matters listed but also there are separately another 85 notices of motion which are also available for discusion this morning. They, of course, come from many honourable members of this place. So, we have 87 notices of motion all listed by honourable members and all of which could have been discussed in this place. Yet, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Opposition chose to take the time of this place in order to discuss this matter. If they wish to do so, the Government raises no objection to Standing Orders being suspended for that purpose.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation. I have actually been given a transcript of the Press conference that I held in Cairo. It was the only time that I made public comments on this subject and was, therefore, the only opportunity the Press had to report any remarks that I might have made. The relevant part of the transcript relates to questions asked by one of the Press people attending the conference. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Question: Would Australia be ready to contribute soldiers towards an international peace-keeping force in the Sinai?

Mr Anthony: Australia has made its position clear. We provide peace-keeping forces when it is under the umbrella of the United Nations and we would hope there will be United Nations support given for a peace-keeping force; otherwise we reserve our position.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said more than that. Read the next page.
—The transcript continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Question: So if you are not under the umbrella of the United Nations are you afraid of Arab reprisals?
Mr Anthony: We don't like to make ad hoc arrangements. We work in accordance with the United Nations resolutions.

Question: Sir, I am sorry to insist but since the Soviet Union will probably veto something like this, what is the attitude of your Government? Would you only participate under the umbrella of the United Nations or would Australia be ready to participate in a multinational force?
Mr Anthony: At this stage the Australian Government has made it clear that it wants to have a United Nations resolution before it gives consideration to sending forces there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you are changing your attitude.

—The newspaper article stated that I said the peacekeeping force would be illegal. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) used the word 'illegal'. There is no mention of the word 'illegal' in the transcript of the Press conference. The word was placed in inverted commas in the Press report this morning. The report is completely inaccurate. I did not say that a peacekeeping force would be illegal without a United Nations resolution. The Leader of the Opposition should not misrepresent the situation. I said that Australia's position was reserved.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. What the Deputy Prime Minister is saying is vastly different from what the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Prime Minister are now saying. There was a much more rigid attitude.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Deputy Prime Minister made a personal explanation. I will not permit the matter to be debated further.
—Mr Speaker--
—I will not call the honourable member for Newcastle. He is not entitled to the call.
—I take a point of order.
—If the honourable gentleman had said so I would have called him.
—My point of order is that the Deputy Prime Minister has quoted partially from a document. I request that he table the whole of that document.

—The honourable gentleman misunderstands the Standing Orders. The point of order relates to another issue. The Deputy Prime Minister quoted from a document because he was making a personal explanation.
—He quoted only partially from it.

—The Deputy Prime Minister quoted from the document. Following an interjection which I permitted, he quoted more of it. The matter is now at an end. The Standing Orders have been suspended to enable the Minister for Foreign Affairs to make a statement if he wishes to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government can understand the interest in this matter but I would have hoped for a much more constructive approach on the part of the Opposition and a willingness to build on the Camp David Accords rather than an attempt to throw doubt on them. Therefore, the first point that needs to be made is that this debate has been brought on at a completely inappropriate time. No formal request has been received from the United States Government or anybody else for us to participate in a peacekeeping force in the Sinai. If and when it is received, the Government will make a decision on it and, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) indicated yesterday, there will be an opportunity for full and proper debate in this House in the event of any decision being taken. The Opposition is fully aware of the Government's current position.

SPEECH.PARA: The question needs to be asked why the Opposition has chosen to bring this matter on at such an inappropriate time. The answer can be only that the Opposition, once again, is attempting to throw a cloud of suspicion and distrust over Australia's alliance with the United States. Furthermore, the Australian Labor Party is revealing a clear ideological bias against the constructive initiatives resulting from the Camp David Accords. The Government fully supported those Accords and the Israel-Egypt peace treaty which followed from them in the firm belief that they constituted the first step towards a more comprehensive statement. The peace treaty envisaged Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai by the end of April 1982. The final Israeli withdrawal was to be monitored by a peacekeeping force under the auspices of the United Nations. Australia, as well as the parties concerned, wishes to see the United Nations sponsor such a peacekeeping force, but all the information currently available to us suggests that it is extremely unlikely that this will be possible because of a likely Soviet veto in the United Nations Security Council. In these circumstances Egypt, Israel and the United States are currently engaged in consultations on the means by which a peace-keeping force may be established in the very probable event that the United Nations is unable to establish the peacekeeping role envisaged for it in the peace treaty.

We understand that the countries concerned have under consideration a multinational force composed of countries acceptable to Israel and Egypt. Although no formal approach has been made to us, as I have already said, we understand that Australia is amongst a number of countries being considered as participants in such a multi- national force. We further understand that a number of Latin American, African and European countries are also being considered as possible contributors to any such force. It is likely also that the United States will contribute. It is our further understanding that such a force would be established solely for a peacekeeping role in the Sinai. It would be an error to ascribe any direct association between this proposal and separate proposals relating to the possible establishment of a rapid deployment force in the region, with which we have not been involved. The Government's concern that it be made quite clear that there would be no link between a proposed Sinai peacekeeping force and any rapid deployment force has been conveyed to the United States Government.

I emphasise that any communications between Australia and the parties concerned can be described only as being of an exploratory nature at this stage. We believe that such an exploratory approach in the present circumstances is both justified and prudent and will contribute to any formal deliberations which might be required of the Government if and when a formal approach is made for Australian participation. As I have said, in accordance with the Government's support for the Camp David Accords and the peace treaty, it attaches importance to the smooth Israeli withdrawal from the final portion of Egyptian territory. This is a means of maintaining the peace process. It is hoped that success in this area will help open the way for more comprehensive peace negotiations in the Middle East. If and when the Government receives an official approach to participate in the Sinai peacekeeping force, it will take into account, in coming to a decision, a wide range of issues affecting our national interests.

Obviously, our preference is and remains in favour of a force which has United Nations sponsorship. As I said earlier, it seems clear that it will not be possible to achieve this. It is important, therefore, that any proposed force cover as wide a political and geographic representation as possible. Moreover, the Government will need to be satisfied about the precise role and command structure for the force. The Government will not commit itself to the force unless it has satisfactory assurances on these matters. The Government believes that the implementation of the Camp David Accords can be seen as the first phase in a lasting and equitable resolution of conflict in the Middle East. For that reason we regard the accords as a set of constructive initiatives which all countries with an interest in peace and justice in the Middle East would want to pursue.

Australia has limited political influence in the Middle East. Our interest is in the maintenance of stability in the region and cannot be described as being limited. The Government has accepted that, where our national interests coincide with those of the Middle East, it should give careful consideration to what contribution, even though it may be limited, it might be able to make towards the maintenance of peace in that region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) rejects the prevailing colonial mentality of the Fraser Government by which technology transfer is overwhelmingly under foreign control;
(2) rejects the concept of technological determinism-the idea that technological changes must be adopted regardless of social consequences, as set out in the CITCA (Myers) Report;
(3) expresses its preference for technologies which complement and enhance human capacity, dignity and diversity;
(4) asserts that the Australian people have the right to choose the most appropriate technologies from the range offering, e.g. solar as opposed to nuclear energy;
(5) believes that introduction, ownership and control of high technology should not be left to market forces alone;
(6) calls on the Fraser Government to follow the example of Switzerland and Sweden in encouraging higher levels of nationally based research and development, and

(7) calls for the establishment of an independent Office of Technology Assessment and a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Science and Technology so that both Houses can take an active and informed role in pursuing national policies on technology.

The House will have an opportunity today to vote on a series of basic propositions about where Australia is going and how it will get there. I hope that the motion will be supported by all honourable members because the area of science and technology is one in where we ought to have a bipartisan approach. I turn briefly, given the hour, to the individual points of my motion. In a number of earlier speeches I have criticised the prevailing colonial mentality of the Fraser Government and my concern that technology transfer is overwhelmingly under foreign control. I think that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) recognised this fact in his address to the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science yesterday. He is well aware that 94 per cent of the royalties or know-how payments in Australia are paid overseas. I hope for and expect his support on this point today. The report of the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia, surely the most lightweight and irrelevant major report ever issued, even by this Government, totally failed to tackle the question of technology transfer. The report ignored the implications of foreign ownership except for one isolated and apparently naive comment. It said:

Technology is, in general, an international commodity and the ability of the Government or people of a small country such as Australia to influence the development of new technologies and their use in the world is probably extremely limited.
That is the end of the statement. That is the report's total comment. The words 'multinational corporation' literally do not appear anywhere in the 1,552 pages of that four-volume report.

Secondly, we ought to reject the concept of technological determinism and restore the significance of Parliament and the political process. Democracy does have its failures, as the past successes of Barabbas, Hitler and Peron indicate. But legislatures, though imperfect, have a greater sensitivity to human needs than any other political instrument. Parliamentarians must raise their consciousness and levels of debate on technology, tapping alternative sources of advice. We should assert the right to choose between varieties of technology. The futures debate in Australia, such as it is, has encouraged the simplistic view that technology must be either adopted in toto in its most advanced form, the sooner the better, or rejected in toto by adopting Buddhist economics and foresaking the flush toilet, the electric blanket and colour television. The debate has ignored our right to select appropriate technologies and to fit them to meet social needs. Technology is not a monolith. There are multitudes of diverse technologies.

If the democratic process is to survive in a period of rapid and insistent technological change, Parliament must assert the right to choose. The right to choose is inextricably linked with the right to be fully informed. The revival of the primacy of the political process in technologically or scientifically based areas does not involve the setting up of cumbersome regulatory apparatuses which are likely to prove irrelevant or anachronistic. Any regulatory body which attempted in the 1960s, for example, to preserve the thermionic valve industry against the competition of transistors would have faced an uphill struggle and it would have failed. It is essential that the Parliament be properly informed of the political, social and economic implications of major technological change so that it is possible to provide answers to questions such as: What are the likely employment effects? Who owns the technology?

The critical issues in technological change are political and economic, not scientific. The Parliament must assert its right of access to information against special interests who are able to manipulate, to distort and to suppress. The Parliament must strengthen its own access to independent, arms-length advice which can enable it to question and, at times, challenge the basis of advice which is presented to a Minister through a Department. This is why the motion calls for the establishment of an independent Office of Technology Assessment similar to the one which operates as a vital agency of the United States Congress and also a parliamentary standing committee on science and technology representing both Houses. I hope that we will have the support of the Minister on that today and that the motion will be carried without opposition.

In addition, adequate and effective freedom of information legislation must be adopted; not freedom from information legislation, as is proposed by the Fraser Government in legislation which is currently before the Senate and which should properly be called the Bureaucratic Procedures Protection Bill. Existing restraints in Australia's defamation laws ought to be eased in this area, too. It is essential that we have a greater information flow in the areas of science and technology policy so that we can demystify science and technology. The mystification is largely a smoke-screen by which people with a special or partisan interest are in a position to slant or distort data and influence its interpretation by omission and suppression. The history of the United States motor industry is a clear example of that, as the book On a Clear Day You Can See General Motors, by J. Patrick Wright and based on the experiences of John Z. De Lorean, indicates so clearly. Detroit's malaise has a direct impact on motor manufacturing in Australia. Suppression and distortion of information is not an aberration. In many areas of enterprise it has been the standard practice.

In the sensitive and vital field of biotechnology, for example, with the consequential ethical problems arising in such areas as the right to patent genetic material, cloning or the implications of dramatic increases in longevity so that the economically active members of the community are greatly outnumbered by the aged, tremendously important questions arise. But how and when will parliament-any parliament, not just our Parliament-address itself to such problems when senior Ministers do not even know what the word 'biotechnology' means and when recombinant DNA might, for all they know, be the zoological name for a fruit bat.

I draw the attention of the House to the New Zealand Planning Act of 1977, which sets up two bodies-the New Zealand Planning Council and the New Zealand Commission for the Future-with the respective duty of stimulating public debate on the short term and long term implications of technological change in New Zealand and of reporting to the Parliament. I seek leave to incorporate section 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, and 10 of the New Zealand Planning Act in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
1. Short Title-This Act may be cited as the New Zealand Planning Act 1977.
2. Interpretation-In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires,-
''Body'' means the Council or the Commission:
''Commission'' means the Commission for the Future established by section 8 (1) of this Act:
''Council'' means the New Zealand Planning Council established by section 4 (1) of this Act:
''Minister'' means the Minister of National Development.
3. Act to bind the Crown-This Act shall bind the Crown.
PART I
New Zealand Planning Council
4. Establishment of New Zealand Planning Council-(1) There is hereby established a council to be called the New Zealand Planning Council.

(2) The Council established by subsection (1) of this section is hereby declared to be the same council as the New Zealand Planning Council established by the Minister and in existence immediately before the commencement of this Act.
5. Functions and powers of Council-(1) The general functions of the Council shall be-
(a) To advise the Government on planning for social, economic, and cultural development in New Zealand:
(b) To assist the Government to co-ordinate such planning:
(c) To comment to the Government on programmes for social, economic, and cultural development in New Zealand, and to recommend the priorities that should be accorded to them:
(d) To act as focal point for a process of consultative planning about New Zealand's medium-term development:
(e) To foster discussion among those agencies (Government and private) concerned with planning, particularly in the economic, environmental, social, and cultural fields:
(f) To submit advice to the Government on links between planning at the national and regional levels:
(g) To prepare reports on any matter affecting the economic, social, or cultural development of New Zealand:
(h) To submit any report prepared by it to the Minister if it thinks fit:
(i) To recommend that any report submitted to the Minister under paragraph (h) of this subsection be laid before Parliament:
(j) To publish documents on planning topics which in the view of the Council merit wide consideration and public debate:

(k) To consider any other matter which is referred to the Council by the Minister or which is relevant to the proper performance of the functions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (j) of this subsection.
(2) The Council shall have such other functions, powers, and duties as are conferred or imposed on it by or under this Act or any other enactment.
(3) The Council shall have such other powers as may be reasonably necessary to enable it to carry out its functions.
6. Membership of Council-(1) The Council shall consist of-
(a) Not more than 12 members to be appointed by the Governor-General on the recommendation of the Minister, of whom one shall be appointed as Chairman:
(b) The Minister:
(c) The Secretary to the Treasury.
(2) In recommending persons for appointment as members of the Council the Minister shall have regard to-
(a) Their personal attributes; and
(b) The need for a diversity of knowledge and experience in fields relevant to the functions of the Council to be present among it members; and
(c) The capacity of the Council as a whole to promote a sense of common purpose among different sections of the community in planning New Zealand's future.
PART II
Commission for the Future
8. Establishment of Commission for the Future-(1) There is hereby established a commission to be known as the Commission for the Future.

(2) The Commision established by subsection (1) of this section is hereby declared to be the same Commission as the Commission for the Future established by the Minister and in existence immediately before the commencement of this Act.
9. Functions of Commission-(1) The general functions of the Commission shall be-
(a) To study the possibilities for the long-term economic and social development of New Zealand:
(b) To make information on those possibilities available to all Members of Parliament, and to publish such information for wider dissemination:
(c) To promote discussion on those possibilities and information relating to them:
(d) To report to the Minister on those possibilities.
(2) In carrying out its general functions the Commission shall-
(a) Give special attention to the long-term implications for New Zealand of new or prospective developments in science and technology; and
(b) Have regard to prospective trends, policies, and events in New Zealand and overseas which could have important consequences for the country's future.
(3) The Commission shall have such other functions, powers, and duties as are conferred or imposed on it by or under this Act or any other enactment.
(4) The Commission shall have such other powers as may be reasonably necessary to enable it to carry out its functions.
10. Membership of Commission-(1) The Commission shall consist of-
(a) Not more than 7 members to be appointed by the Governor-General on the recommendation of the Minister, of whom one shall be appointed as Chairman:
(b) A Minister of the Crown to be appointed by the Minister of National Development:
(c) A Member of Parliament to be appointed by the Minister on the nomination of the Leader of the Official Opposition:
(d) A member of the Council to be appointed by the Minister on the nomination of the Chairman of the Council:
(e) The Director-General of the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research.
(2) In recommending persons for appointment as members of the Commission under subsection (1) (a) of this section, the Minister shall have regard to-
(a) Their personal attributes; and
(b) The need for a diversity of knowledge and qualifications in fields relevant to the functions of the Commission to be present among its members.

(3) Any Minister of the Crown designated for the time being by the Minister of National Development as an alternate member of the Commission may act as a member of the Commission in the place of the Minister for the time being holding office as a member of the Commission under sub- section (1) (b) of this section.

(4) The fact that any Minister of the Crown acts as a member of the Commission in the place of the member for the time being holding office under subsection (1) (b) of this section shall be conclusive evidence of his authority to do so.

11. Term of office of members of Commission-(1) Except as otherwise provided by this Act, every member of the Commission appointed under section 10 (1) (a) of this Act shall hold office for such term as the Governor-General on the recommendation of the Minister shall specify in his appointment, being a term not exceeding 3 years, but may from time to time be reappointed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I will read the critical part of that Act relating to the duty of the Commission for the Future. Section 9 states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The general functions of the Commission shall be-
(a) To study the possibilities for the long-term economic and social developments of New Zealand:
(b) To make information on those possibilities available to all Members of Parliament, and to publish such information for wider dissemination:
(c) To promote discussion on these possibilities and information relating to them:
(d) To report to the Minister on those possibilities.

The Commission is also asked to give special attention to the long term implications to New Zealand of new or prospective developments in science and technology. Essentially the Commission has stimulated public debate by producing a series of very important reports which are then circulated to schools, councils and interested citizens. This provokes an ongoing debate in which Ministers and members of parliament are directly involved. I think that is a wholesome tendency.

The technology which Ministers and members of parliament ignore at their peril is capable of making them obsolete. Of the 12 or so major functions of a member of parliament which I can identify, all but one could be done more cheaply and more efficiently by computers. The sole exception is, of course, speech making. If within a decade or two our functions are taken over by robots we will have nobody to blame but ourselves. This motion gives us the chance to express our collective will on the subject. I call on honourable members who believe that the House has the right and the duty to be informed and to make choices where appropriate to support the motion. Its rejection would say that we have abdicated our right as a parliament to choose and the age of robots and 1984 will sweep democracy away.

Technology-that is, the technological arte- facts themselves-is politically, economically and morally neutral. The decisive questions for us and for the nation relate entirely to the issue of who owns the technology and to what end it is used. This can be illustrated by a short list of examples-telephones, television, Xerox machine, communications satellites and computers. Where telephones are readily available at low cost with easy access to directories and where the lines are not bugged they can be instruments of liberation, enlarging personal freedoms and opening up a wider world of knowledge and experience, strengthening the position of individuals vis-a-vis their rulers. On the other hand, where there is tight central control over telephone systems, coupled with bugging, lack of telephone directories and a very small number of telephones available to subscribers so that if A wants to phone B he has to ask the controllers of the telephone system for the number and explain why he is doing it, the telephone can be-and is-used as an instrument of surveillance, strengthening the central bureaucracy vis-a-vis the individual.

Similarly, television can be used to stimulate and inform or to stupefy, to oversimplify and to coerce. The key factor is not the technology itself but the use to which it is put. The Xerox machine can be a revolutionary instrument in the cause of freedom of information. Material can be, and indeed is, leaked or disseminated with speed and precision. In the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics the Xerox machine is seen as an instrument of counter revolution and dry copiers are kept under very tight control, out of the reach of ordinary citizens. The communications satellite is particularly ambiguous. It can be used to widen access to information from a variety of citizens and interest groups, to strenghten the periphery relative to the centre and to effect a massive redistribution of power in the information sector and, of course, to be a common carrier at low cost. But is this what we are going to get? On the other hand, the satellite can be, and in Australia almost certainly will be, used to intensify the present media oligopoly and its controllers will be the Murdochs, the Packers and their camp followers. Its effect will be to strengthen the centre relative to the periphery. This is why we state in the motion that these things are too important to be left to the market. Just as Clemenceau said in the First World War that war was too important to be left to the generals, so science and technology is too important to be left to the scientists and the technologists or to the people who, by their ownership of capital, control access to and dominate science and technology.

Computers can end dull, repetitive and dangerous jobs and lead to a major and more equitable redistribution of employment and wealth. They can also be used to decimate employment without any compensating redistribution and to intensify the gap between rich and poor, the skilled and the unskilled.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As it is now two hours after time fixed for the meeting of the House the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent consideration of General Business notice No. 1 being continued until 1 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House and the Minister for Science and Technology. I believe that we are entering into an extremely critical period-one of the most critical periods in our history. I return to my central argument. There is a prevailing view that in a small country like Australia the whole question of technology transfer should be left to the global market. In other words, if something is adopted, pursued and pushed we in Australia simply adopt it, we acquire the technology off the shelf. I think that members of all parties recognise the dangers implicit in that. It will be a very serious problem if Australia is merely a technological colony.
—Major areas are vertically integrated anyhow.

—Absolutely. There are a number of other small countries of which Sweden and Switzerland are outstanding examples, with comparatively small but highly skilled populations. It is possible for them to play a very important role in the world market because they have kept control of their own technology. The technology is theirs. In Australia we cannot sell what essentially we do not own. That is why it is a hollow piece of hypocrisy to talk about the Australian motor car industry. There is not an Australian motor car industry. Australians are employed in a motor car industry which is owned and controlled overseas. But it is not our industry. We have a completely derivative technology.

SPEECH.PARA: Politicians are often unjustly pilloried. But it is essential that the parliament asserts its right to be central in the determination of policy about where we are going. But parliamentarians are faced with an information overload of such dimensions that it discourages rather than encourages investigation of complex issues. We are understaffed and outmanoeuvred by a very numerous public service. As a result, Parliament has been encouraged to lose collective confidence in its capacity to take any position at all in a technologically shaped society. We have the worst informed legislature in the world on scientific and technical matters, lacking the resources or the intellectual vitality to initiate a national debate on where we are going or how we are getting there. In the thirty-first Parliament between 1977 and 1980, there were two 50-minute debates related to science and technology for the three-year period. Only one of Australia's 784 members of parliament made a submission to the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—Modesty prevents me from identifying him. There is no committee on science and technology for the Parliament as a whole although the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment has done valuable work. Parliament has proved almost totally incapable of taking any collective position on the social impact of technological change and has retreated into an embarrassed silence, almost indistinguishable from a catatonic trance. Questions on science policy are received with dismay especially when the Minister is overseas. A question to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on what action the Government was taking to respond to the enormous challenges of biotechnology was shunted off to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) with manifest confusion on all sides.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to get the best and not the worst out of science and technology, to make sure that we retain high levels of employment, that we encourage people to develop their own personal skills, that we try to do what we can to make sure that there is a preference expressed for the kind of employment which complements and enhances human capacity, dignity and diversity, then we cannot leave this simply to the market. Of course, market factors are very important. They are not to be disregarded; they must be taken into account. However, they are only part of a whole number of factors. Economic efficiency and social efficiency are not exact equivalents. Other factors have to be taken into account. My own electorate from a point of view of economic efficiency is outstandingly successful with, I would think, probably the highest amount of value added of any electorate in Australia. Nevertheless, from a point of view of social efficiency Lalor has appalling unemployment and the possibility of future social tensions. I hope that the Minister will indicate that the Government will accept the motion. We should have a bipartisan policy on this matter. I ask all honourable members to support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cass The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion moved by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). Considering the long time that this motion, proposed by the honourable member for Lalor, has been on the Notice Paper I am amazed that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) could be so badly advised by his Department that he could come into the House on Tuesday and make such a vapid, ineffectual speech when tabling the Science and Technology statement for 1980-81. In the main, the statement is, of course, a rather dull, pedestrian account of levels of expenditure on research and development. It attempts to make the best of our efforts. The Ministerial Statement was sparsely peppered with significant observations which one fears may not have been understood by the Minister and which certainly were not understood by the Liberal-National Country Party Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Activities in a number of departments, which I would have thought had nothing to do with research and development and which I would not have expected to be acknowledged in a science and technology statement, are listed. I will select just one of these activities to illustrate what I mean. On page 49 of the report, in the section describing research and development conducted by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, it was stated:
expenditure in 1979-80 on R&D into English language needs was $191,000, while expenditure on the survey of migrant information needs was $74,000.

I am not suggesting that these activities should not have been pursued; of course we should know about the needs of migrants. I argue that perhaps the way it was done could have been better or different, but that is not the point. However discovered, is such information-which any government should have-really a result of research and development? On page 101 of the report we find a definition of research and development which states among other things that:
R&D ceases when work is no longer experimental.

Was any of that work ever experimental? It would be horrifying to know how much of the effort included in the statement was research and development-but which clearly is not-has boosted the value of our effort expressed as a percentage of gross domestic product. Even with this padding, our effort is embarrassingly inadequate compared to that of other countries we would care to compare ourselves with.

I will now refer to the motion proposed by the Australian Labor Party and the speech by the Minister which, perhaps accidentially, addressed itself to the number of issues raised by the honourable member for Lalor in moving the motion. We in the Opposition object to the almost total dependence of this country on the importation of technological innovation. To be fair to the Minister, on page 2232 of Hansard he observes:

It is a paradox that, in order to apply science more directly and effectively to problems, we must extend our knowledge of basic science. Without this foundation successful technology transfer will not be possible.

I do not know how the Minister understands his own statement; we are almost totally dependent on the transfer of technology from overseas via the large corporations which are so rapidly increasing their penetration of so much of Australian industry. In fact, that penetration is so extensive that we can assert that these industries now have a stranglehold on a distressingly large number of key industrial areas such as chemicals, drugs, mineral extraction and processing, plastics, petroleum and other industries. These industries tend to be the ones most affected by technological innovation. In this instance the transfer of new technology to Australia is almost totally in the hands of these foreign-owned corporations.

Over the years, with the expansion of such interests in Australia, trans-national corporations have at times poached our skilled workers, transferred them to their base countries and then closed down the Australian research establishments. I know of a case where a range of new products was discovered by an Australian team working in this country. The research team was taken to America-they are employed by a subsidiary of the company here-where the key research worker after a time was offered a permanent appointment at the head office, the Australian laboratories of the company were closed and the rest of the team declared redundant. Australia then had to purchase the new technology from that company even though it had been discovered and developed mainly in Australia. The research worker objected to these takeover tactics and returned to Australia where he joined the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. He has been able to continue his work. However, his early work is owned by the transnational organisation and not by Australia.

I return to the main point of whether the Minister understands the full impact of his comments and our objections to this situation. In a sense the question is academic because in practical terms no matter what the Minister thinks it is quite clear from the Government's action that it either does not know or does not care-if it does know-what the prospect means. The problem exists at two levels. Firstly, basic research, often overlapping and dependent upon other research in perhaps seemingly different areas, nonetheless may help to spark the idea or suggest a lateral approach to the investigation of the problem and will facilitate the breakthrough to the discovery of a new process-a technological innovation. Thus we need a community of research establishments and basic research workers if we wish to be in and part of the growing edge of scientific innovation which will ensure for us a place in the sun-for the whole country not just the particular research group. The discovery and the basic research is only the beginning. The idea has to be developed and implemented and the transfer to the rest of the community has to take place. I quote the Minister's brave words on page 2230-1 of the Hansard where he stated:
. . . the science and technology sector should not be considered in isolation.
The Minister continued:
Scientific, economic and social policies must be integrated.
Later he stated:
The plan is to stimulate and support basic research, applied research, to transfer research results into the market place and to minimise any undesirable impacts of new technologies.

These are brave words but we need more than brave words. Where is the evidence of the Government's understanding of the problem or of the implications resulting from the razor gang's slaughter and the cut back in resources for tertiary institutions at all levels? How about the cut backs in teacher training which thus reduces the number of qualified people to teach the young who may aspire to become our research workers of the future? What about cutbacks in colleges of advanced education and universities at lecturer and general staffing levels so there are neither the places for, nor the people to train, aspiring research workers? What about the limitation on future research resulting from the imposition of fees on graduates studying for a second, usually higher, degree during the course of which much of the basic research work is done in the universities? As a result, aspiring researchers who manage to get their basic training, unless they are able to depend on a rich daddy or supporting spouse, will have to get a job out in the real world. There is to be no wasting time or taxpayers' money doing basic research on impractical, esoteric problems in ivory towers. Clearly the Government, this collection of intellectually cretinous liberals, whose range of vision does not extend beyond the primitive dirt track, did not understand the Minister when he said:

The great social and humanitarian reforms of the last century were largely possible because of increased industrial productivity, better health services and improved communications. Science and technology played a major role.
I will repeat the Minister's words:
Science and technology played a major role.
The Minister continued:
It is equally true that science and technology will underwrite Australia's economic and social development in the future.

The Opposition heartily agrees. I say: 'Lift your eyes, you lazy Liberal lotus eaters; we cannot for ever depend on others, on rich and powerful friends to forcefeed us forever, to carry us along in their arms'. We have to develop the knowledge and skills to nurture our own development and growth. We must walk-dare I suggest it, even run-on our own feet just to keep up with the ever-increasing rate of progress.

That is only the first point arising from the Minister's observation of the paradox. He seems to believe that others can do better and bigger research, and he forever asserts that duplication is wasteful. It is an article of faith of this mindless Liberal Government whose thoughts run along a single track. It is an arrogant and ignorant assumption that there is only one way to approach these problems. Why does the Minister assume that two research workers seemingly setting out to do the same research will inevitably tread the same ground? He talks so much about initiative and enterprise. Why does he not believe in it? Can he not see that, even if teams of researchers start off at the same point, inevitably they will diverge? Is that not how it all happens? Is not the richness and diversity of humanity due to just that?

For the sake of the second point which arises from the Minister's comments, let us accept his blinkered view of the extension of knowledge. I remind honourable members again of the Minister's words, with which we on this side of the House agree. He stated:
. . . in order to apply science more directly and effectively to problems, we must extend our knowledge of basic science.

The Australian Labor Party agrees with that. What is most significant is that we understand and believe in that philosophy while quite clearly the Minister, if he understands and believes in it, is on his own. Clearly his Liberal and National Country Party colleagues do not know what he is talking about, nor do they care. If we wish to overcome the problem of technology transfer, which is overwhelmingly under foreign control, and the associated enormous prices we have to pay for it-perhaps a comment on the cost will stir the petty shopkeeper, ledger clerk minds of members of the Government to take notice-and if we wish to control technology transfer ourselves we must have more and not less basic research. We have to do our own basic research.

In arguing how to overcome this ignorance on the part of Government politicians, to enable us to deal with some of the concerns expressed by the Minister, I wish to quote his words again. On page 2230 of Hansard, he said:

Over the past decade there have been significant changes in community attitudes to science and technology which cannot be ignored. Presently there is concern about job replacing technology, the environment, the availability of a highly skilled work force and a continuing supply of energy. In addition, I sense a growing fear of the impact of science and technology among the less well informed.

To enable intelligent decisions to be taken and effective action to be implemented in relation to the first six points raised by the honourable member for Lalor in his motion, as well as the points raised by the Minister, we call for the action proposed in the final point of the motion. That point is that the Opposition:

calls for the establishment of an Independent Office of Technology Assessment and a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Science and Technology so that both Houses can take an active and informed role in pursuing national policies on technology.

This approach is reminiscent of the approach the Labor Party considered when it was in government was necessary in regard to the environment. It is rather like the environmental impact statement approach. The proponent prepares an EIS on whatever it is he is putting forward. We suggest that we call it a technological impact statement which should be prepared by the proponent, giving all facets of the problem, including all the advantages, all the disadvantages and all the costs. Of course, one could not expect that impact statement to be unbiased; clearly, it would be the views of the proponent. In order to assess that we would need what we propose-namely, an independent office of technology assessment to assess the impact statements, to assess whatever is going on in the whole technology innovation area and then to make recommendations to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, to the Parliament.

—I ask the honourable member to hold on-the recommendations would be to the Government. The question is: How will that be done? How will we cope with items 2, 3, and 4 that the honourable member for Lalor has mentioned? They are, firstly, that we reject the concept of technological determinism. How will we make assessments on that? We think we should express preference for technologies which complement and enhance human capacity, dignity and diversity. How will we do that? The Australian people have a right to choose the most appropriate technologies from the range offering. How will we do all that? It is only by these reports being presented to the Parliament and to a parliamentary standing committee on science and technology that we can encompass and understand these facts. It is not done in mad debate in this chamber, the way we carry on in this chamber; it will be done only when we have the set up what the Opposition proposes so that these issues can be fully understood by honourable members on both sides of the House. Then and only then will we get an intelligent approach to the impact of technology on Australia in the future. I support the recommendation proposed by the honourable member for Lalor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) for giving Parliament an opportunity to debate this very important issue. However, I very much regret that the ineptitude of the Opposition has cut our time short very much indeed. I will have only a few minutes, and there will be only one speaker from the Government side. It is a great pity that such an important debate should have been cut short by the inept meanderings that went on before this debate commenced.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very flattered that so much of what I said this week in my statement on science and technology was quoted by the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Dr Cass) and the honourable member for Lalor. It is flattering to think that they agree with what I said. I said it, I mean it and so does the Government mean it. The Government has a well-defined policy in this very important area but I have great problems in defining any policy from the meanderings of the Opposition. The wide-ranging debates we have had in the last couple of weeks on this issue have not suggested one piece of Opposition policy. There has been none at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just told you.

—There was no policy in that. The honourable member meandered and quoted, but there was no policy. I appreciate the difficulties that the Opposition has in drawing up a policy in this area. Sections of the trade union movement are demanding that there should be no new technology without their permission.
—That is not true.

—It is not nonsense; they have said it many times. The Opposition knows it is true but finds it very difficult to handle. I know the honourable member for Lalor has never said one word about this in any of the wide-ranging speeches he has made on the subject. At the same time, the trade union movement seeks a 35-hour week based almost entirely upon increased productivity caused by the introduction of technology. It is a battle between the Luddites of the Australian Labor Party who still wish to smash the machines, and the realists who see technology as an extension of the worker's arm. I will come back to that later. I would be very pleased to hear a debate in this House on science and technology in which the Opposition put forward a realistic policy. The Opposition talks about multinational corporations. It has a fixation about the multinationals. Members of the Opposition also have a fixation with the fact that governments-particularly Labor governments-can decide what is best for the people.
—Parliaments, not governments.
—We are debating the subject now in this Parliament. The Opposition wants to set up all sorts of control mechanisms.
—No, I did not say that.

—The honourable member suggested an independent office of technological assessment. There are thousands of pieces of technology developed and adopted every year. It would be impossible to assess that whole range. Unfortunately, I have very little time. I will not be able to make most of the points I wish to make. There is no doubt that the Government believes that science and technology should not be considered in isolation. Science and technology and social and economic policies must be integrated. I emphasise that, and I believe it. The plan which I outlined in the statement on science and technology is well worth looking at. But, as a government which believes in free enterprise, we believe that the market should largely determine economic priority. The market is a reflection of what people want.
—On Wednesday you said it should not be left to market forces alone.

—I will come to that in a moment. Labor believes that governments know best, that they can dictate to the people what should be done in relation to science and technology. I did say that in some areas the market is deficient or, because of the pace of technological change, is too slow to adapt to public demands and overseas trends. In this area we believe in limited government intervention to assist industry, as we do with the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme. That is a very important scheme. It is a measure of government intervention to correct an area where market forces are not operating either correctly or fast enough. Unfortunately, the time allowed for this debate is running out and I will not be able to mention many of the points I wished to deal with. As I have mentioned, there have been many changes in community attitudes. They need to be monitored, taken account of and assessed.
—Who is doing it?
—The honourable member knows that the Australian Science and Technology Council is setting up an office of technological assessment.
—But it is not accountable to Parliament.

—The Council will report to me and I am accountable to the Parliament. I wish to make a point about the problem of monitoring technological change, the objective of enhancing skills, and the quality of the work force and how this may be achieved. In this regard I wish to quote from a statement made by Mr Frank Chapple, the General Secretary of the powerful British Electronics, Telecommunications and Plumbing Union, which has about 450,000 members. Mr Chapple said:

SPEECH.PARA: Trade unions should support the development of new technology, and efficient production while simultaneously ensuring that working people share its benefits and do not become its ignored victims.
He went on to say:
This means that I believe--
That is, Mr Chapple believes-

trade unions should not oppose change but demand its acceleration: That we should take a lead in persuading industry to modernise and innovate; that we should campaign for higher productivity, greater wealth creation and for large scale investments in productive sectors of the economy.

I could not agree more. I wish we could have a bipartisan policy. I wish that the honourable member for Lalor would get up an say something like Mr Chapple said and support this philosophical approach to the whole problem of technological change and the introduction of high technology industries. It is a great pity that in Australia we do not have in the trade union movement, in the Australian Labor Party generally or in the Opposition any far-sighted people who are prepared to get up and say: 'We should be co-operating. We should be encouraging industry to innovate. We should encourage technological change'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Re-read the motion.
—The motion is emotive. It is exaggerated. It tries to make some points--
—Why don't you touch on it?

—I would touch on it except my time is now running out. I would have been able to touch on it if the honourable member had given me time to do so and if he had been able to control his side of the House so as to allow me time to touch upon those points in this very important debate. I do not have time to deal with them, which is a great pity. If the honourable member had given me a couple of minutes more in which to speak and if the honourable member for Maribyrnong had cut his speech a little instead of taking his full time, I might have had a chance to respond. But they did not do that. I do not accept this motion. I agree that we should have a bipartisan approach. There are elements of the motion with which I would have a fair measure of agreement, but the motion is emotive and exaggerated. It talks of technological determinism. How many people would understand what the honourable member for Lalor was talking about?
—But they should. That is the point.

—But the honourable member did not explain what he meant. I cannot accept the motion. Although I welcomed the opportunity to debate the issue, I feel that it is a great pity that it could not have been conducted more fully.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Barry Jones's) be agreed to.
