TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourble members, I present the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on certain monomers, prepolymers and goods of the silicone type.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill is a daunting one. It is to enact a very large number of tariff changes involving such major industries as the textiles, clothing and footwear, iron and steel, chemicals, carpets, gearboxes and rural products. The rural products include apples, pears and cheese. Of course, any Bill such as this Bill should be an integral part of an industry policy. The objective of industry policy, as far as the Australian Labor Party is concerned, is to create one and a half million new jobs in the 1980s. A net increase of one million people is expected in the work force in the 1980s. When the hidden unemployed are taken into consideration, there are at least half a million people who want jobs and who should have jobs right now in 1981. The industry policy displayed by this Government in Bills such as the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill is totally inadequate-a fact which goes almost without saying. I will say more about the Bill before I enlarge further on what industry policy should be.

SPEECH.PARA: Tariff changes have been announced in no less than 18 proposals introduced over the past 12 months. These proposals deal with, firstly, changes in the preferential rate of tariff to apply to certain goods from developing countries; secondly, changes in arrangements relating to our trade with New Zealand under the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement; and, thirdly, the new arrangements for closer trading relationships with several Pacific island countries which are signatories with Australia to the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement. Clearly, therefore, this is a very important and wide-ranging Bill. Yet, to the detriment of Australian trade and industry, the Bill will pass with a minimum of public notice and with only limited parliamentary scrutiny. Despite the central importance of these measures to the future economic development of this country, despite the repeated attempts by the Opposition to improve the parliamentary process in relation to tariffs and excise and despite the loud but empty noises of the so-called free traders-or are they now called 'dries'-on the Liberal back bench, these measures will never be fully considered within the context of an industrial development strategy for Australia while we continue using the present mechanisms.

The Bill we are presently debating is of direct relevance to the jobs of hundreds of thousands of Australians. Moreover, it relates to the overall pattern of our economic development. It deserves to be scrutinised properly by this Parliament. Accordingly, the Opposition will move an amendment to the motion that this Bill be read a second time. Past Ministers for Business and Consumer Affairs have indicated their agreement in principle with the Opposition views I have put time and again in the last few years. But there has been no evidence of any action to date. At this stage, so the House knows what I am talking about, I move as a second reading amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not opposing this Bill, the House is of the opinion that a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Customs and Excise Tariffs should be established to examine each change in customs and excise tariffs following the gazettal of proposals or their being introduced into the Parliament on the one hand and before related Bills are introduced into the House on the other'.

In moving the amendment, the Opposition again is expressing its concern that changes in tariffs and trading relations should not be developed and implemented in isolation but should, as I mentioned at the beginning of this speech, be considered in the context of overall industry and trade policy objectives. The fact that this Bill enacts so many changes at once may give the impression that the changes have been devised in conformity with a rational and coherent strategy. That is not so. There is no rational and coherent strategy in the measures validated in this Bill. Nothing could be further from the truth than that assertion. Any impression of coherence or planning in the Bill is an illusion. Industry policy under the Fraser Government conforms to no plan and lacks any uniformity of direction. The proposals were all conceived in splendid isolation one from another. They were not developed against a background of understanding as to where Australian industry should be developed, or so it would seem. The tariff decisions of this Government, like so many other decisions that it takes on economic and social issues, derive from a shaky marriage between free-market fundamentalism on the one hand and political expediency on the other hand.

This same amalgam was the basis of the Government's industry policy decisions following the recent razor gang report. The Government's free market fundamentalists, its small government protagonists, told the Government that it had to make the amount of money to be saved look impressive. What did it do? Without the slightest regard for an industry strategy or a rational business policy, it reduced the investment allowance from 20 per cent to 18 per cent and, more importantly from my point of view, it reduced depreciation acceleration by a similar proportion. What a remarkable achievement that was. Other countries with which we have to compete, particularly if we are to create those extra jobs which we must create to get back to full employment, give accelerated depreciation more generously in order to update machinery and to become more competitive, and therefore increase export trade and be able to compete with imports. This country is not an island on its own; it has to take note of what others are doing. That is not what is happening here. These fundamentalists came along with their ideology of small government and overnight they slashed depreciation rates at a time when our competitors were increasing the amount of depreciation manufacturers could claim in order to become more competitive. How clever that is.

Here we have the strange result of a meeting of rhetoric and expediency, a government which is penny wise but pound foolish. All it does for industry is create more paper work and more difficult tax accounting, and increase uncertainty about the direction this Government is taking. As was said by Mr Eric Risstrom in a letter that all honourable members received the other day, these depreciation changes apparently date from 30 April. Because that is part of the way through the financial year-with only May and June to go-that means that all depreciation schedules will be about twice as large, while one rate of depreciation is claimed for ten-twelfths of the year and another rate is claimed for two-twelfths of the year. All of this is done in the name of efficiency and in the name of productivity, yet it is only creating more problems for the private sector, just as it is for many people in the public sector.

The tariff changes in this Bill display the same failure of rational planning. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) is so busy with the task of holding his ailing party together and propping up his failing leader that industry policy in Australia remains a backwater. Industry policy under this Government responds more to the ebb and flow of the electoral cycle than it does to rational, forward looking strategy. Of course, the casualty is industrial development and the creation of that one and half million jobs to which I referred earlier. I emphasise that it is industrial development that is the casualty and not the corporate sector, which has the principal role of pursuing industrial development. The corporate sector is doing very well out of this Government in certain sectors. The foreign-owned sector is doing particularly well and at present the rate of foreign takeovers is proceeding at a pace of $7 billion a year.

Local and foreign corporations are enjoying resurgent profits as a result of unconstrained pricing policies, inadequate taxing policies in the mining sector and the scuttling of effective trade practices legislation. The attraction of foreign investors and burgeoning corporate profits is not synonymous with optimal industrial development. Foreign takeovers and massive profits are the antithesis of what is needed because the inequalities which they exacerbate lead to a breakdown in the social conditions needed for sustained industrial growth. Worker management co-operation for mutually beneficial economic development is neither warranted nor possible under the conditions of deliberately increased inequality which are fostered by so many of the policies of this Fraser Government which we are enduring at this time. This all points to the continuing urgent need for the processes of industry policy development in this country, of which tariffs are a major part, to be radically overhauled.

The Labor Opposition's approach to industry policy differs in three fundamental respects from the approach of the Government. Firstly, we believe that a degree of long term planning is essential for Australia. Clearly we need to establish our industry objectives and then apply them with the benefit of a clear understanding of the capital, labour and structural adjustment requirements of our industries. Australia remains one of the very few countries in which a long term indicative view is not taken by government and industry. We should emulate what the Japanese do in their work, with their economic planning agency. They have a medium and long term perspective in relation to their objectives. We should try to emulate what is going on in Holland, France and in many other countries, even where there are non-socialist governments. They see the wisdom of forecasting and getting some unity when it comes to the objectives of the private and public sectors. Such an attitude is all the more important in a federation such as ours where, at the same time as seeking that unity of objectives between the public and private sectors, we should be seeking to the greatest extent possible a unified approach to objectives on the part of State governments as well as the Commonwealth Government.

The second area where the Opposition differs from this conservative Government in power at the moment is in seeking a co-operative approach towards the formulation and implementation of economic strategies. We believe that consultation with industry is essential and that organisations of labour must also be directly involved in these planning processes. At the moment we are witnessing once again, as a result of the activities of the infamous razor gang, a diminution in industry consultation. The number of industry advisory councils is decreasing and there is less likelihood of business people involving themselves in the consultation than has happened hitherto, even though that activity of consultation to this time has been inadequate.

Thirdly, the Opposition believes that in a small country such as ours market forces alone are not adequate to determine either prices or patterns of output. We realise that the fight against inflation and the task of expanding investment in manufacturing require substantial government participation and leadership. In come cases, regulation is essential; in many other cases, positive incentives must be provided to ensure that appropriate expenditures in such areas as small business development, industrial research and development and export market development are carried through. This Government does not believe in forward planning; it does not believe in consultation; and it abdicates its responsibility to provide leadership to our industrial sector. As I said earlier, at the moment it is so pre-occupied with the divisions within its own ranks that it is not giving any sort of leadership in any direction. Instead, it makes one ad hoc decision after another in the course of each year and uses devices such as this Customs Tariff Amendment Bill to give legislative authority to its actions.

I wish to give further examples of the lack of coherence in protection in industry policy as it exists at present. We find that the rates of protection for some goods have increased and for others they have decreased. There appears to be no logical pattern. Certainly the decisions are not usually the result of Industries Assistance Commission recommendations; they are in the face of those recommendations. For example, duty rates on carpet imports were increased dramatically without any reference to importers and retailers in the industry. That was an ad hoc decision; it was made at the last moment by this Government in 1980 when it was particularly electorally sensitive. Had that decision been made I have no doubt that it would have been different. That is what I mean when I refer to electoral expediency as the motive for some of these decisions.

Another example is the assistance arrangements in regard to steel. In its draft report the IAC initially sought a combination of limited tariff protection and export assistance. Nothing happened for over a year. The IAC, supported by the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd, then sought much the same tariff regime as in the draft report, supplemented by additional assistance for investment in the form of accellerated depreciation. This Bill implements the tariff changes, but the depreciation changes are left up in the air. The industry has invested little in new or more modern capacity over the past several years, despite the fact that demand for steel will grow strongly in the period of resource-based investment which is now under way. Here, I allege, is a classic example of a lack of forward planning on the one hand, and an absence of policy co-ordination on the other. The investment should have been under way by now. The company is still holding off because only half of the relevant policy decisions have been taken. Along with every other manufacturer in Australia, all that the steel industry has heard from the Government is that 2 per cent is to be shaved off depreciation and the investment allowance. That was the message it received in late April, and it is extremely concerned about what further messages there will be in August when the Budget is brought down.

Before closing my remarks and resuming my seat, I draw the attention of the House to the fact that three of the tariff proposals which are the subject of this Bill are more than six months old. Tariff Proposals 18, 19 and 20 of 1980 were introduced on 2 December last year and, accordingly, the six-month period during which the Customs Act provides protection for the collection of duties has now expired. These proposals have not been subject to a validation Bill, and the collector of customs duty is not at present protected by legislation. Of course, this situation will be rectified by the passage of this Bill, and it will have appropriate retrospective effect. However, it should not pass without notice that it is only because the courts of law in Australia typically suffer considerable delays that the Government is not today in a very embarrassing situation. It is also worth recording that in this case we have an example of the sloppy government of which we have seen so many examples recently. The Government is so busy defending itself from its own back bench and from disaffected former Ministers that the good and proper government of this country is allowed to take second place. This is a shabby, indeed contemptuous, way, to treat the Parliament. The six months validation period for tariffs has been all but ignored.

In summary, not only is there that mistake in this Bill, but also there is the sad fact that in spite of it being drawn to the attention of the Government on a number of occasions that there should be more detailed attention given by the Parliament to the various proposals gazetted, indeed, no movement has been ascertained on that subject. We ask the new Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) to apply his mind to the concept of the Parliament scrutinising these proposals more carefully so that greater attention is given by the representatives of the people to the important proposals that are given to the Parliament. There is an analogy in the Senate, where the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances gives detailed attention to ordinances that are brought down. I believe that such detailed attention should be given to these proposals by a committee of this Parliament. The proposals come down; there is no delay of a week while they are studied, and no time is given by the Leader of the House for each of those proposals to be debated. We wait virtually for six months, until either a validation Bill comes in at the end of the calendar year or a Bill such as this one comes in near the end of the financial year, before the proposals are debated. They are then a fait accompli. Debate on the individual proposals is a waste of time.

All one can do, leading for the Opposition, is what I have done-draw attention again to the need for better procedures, draw attention again to how important it is that proposals such as the 21 or so covered by this measure should be part of a coherent industry policy which looks at the medium and long-term objectives of the country. There is no greater objective than that secondary industry should be very healthy. Our resource-based industries will provide only about one-third of the extra 1.5 million new jobs that we need in the 1980s. We need secondary industries and their related tertiary industries, the services sector, to provide the extra jobs if we are to get back to full employment. Bills such as this one should be seen in that context. They will be so seen when there is a change of government and the Australian Labor Party is able to apply its medium and long term planning attitudes to the government of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The section of the general debate on which I want to concentrate this afternoon is the Industries Assistance Commission report on cheese. It was published on 15 March 1979, so we are now talking about a report which was completed two years ago. This final debate in Parliament ends seven years in which the dairying industry of this country has been subjected to almost continuous IAC hearings. There were three hearings in all, two general and one on cheese. The first hearing was required by the Labor Government when it phased out the old dairy bounty and removed all support for the dairying industry at a time when that industry was going through a trauma following the entry of Britain into the European Economic Community. Seven years and three IAC hearings, I suggest, is too long, costly and uncertain for any industry in this country to be subjected to, and I hope that the dairying industry, or any other industry in Australia for that matter, is not again subjected to such a process. I am pleased that one of the IAC recommendations is that there should be no further IAC inquiries into the dairying industry for a period of five years.

SPEECH.PARA: In its inquiries into the dairying industry the IAC has always recommended that the industry is deserving of assistance. We should compare that with the great majority of IAC reports on manufacturing industry, which generally recommend a reduction of protection. It is unfortunate that generally the IAC does not report on tertiary industry, which has the greatest level of protection of any of the three forms of industry in this country. It is obvious, reading through the IAC reports on the dairying industry, that the IAC had some difficulty in mastering its brief.

In regard to cheese, the delay in tabling and now the debate on the report follow the Multilateral Trade Negotiations and the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement arrangements. The recommendations came at a time when the Multilateral Trade Negotiations were under way, and there are provisions in NAFTA which can and do prolong a final decision. The final IAC recommendations on cheese were different in some degree from the draft recommendations, particularly in regard to bounty if the $200 per tonne which it recommended as a tariff for all cheese coming into Australia could not be implemented against New Zealand because of Schedule A of NAFTA. It also dealt in greater definition with other matters including the cheese quota in relation to New Zealand than it had in the draft report. The report states that cheese should be dutiable at $200 per tonne from all sources; or, failing agreement with New Zealand on this recommendation, assistance through the tariff being replaced by a bounty equivalent to $200 per tonne on all goods under reference produced and consumed in Australia.

I want to make two points in relation to the report. The first relates to the IAC recommendations and to government action in general on those recommendations. In all the IAC investigations into various rural industries in this country the IAC has always stated, to my knowledge, that there is very little or no protection-in some cases minus protection-and therefore some protection or assistance is deserved. Secondly, generally speaking, the manufacturing industries are not efficient by world standards, in contrast with rural industries, and therefore there should be a reduction in protection rather than an increase. It is of interest that usually the Government has not accepted the full recommendations of the IAC in relation to the rural industries. The level of support quite often is less than that recommended. That is so in the case of the IAC report on cheese.

If one looks at the IAC report on the superphosphate bounty, which the Australian Labor Party likes to quote from time to time, one will see that the recommendation is for a bounty of 20 per cent of the cost. If the superphosphate bounty was now 20 per cent of the cost it would be about two-thirds higher than it is at present. One of the few IAC investigations into the non-manufacturing or non-rural industries-the one into the performing arts-was very interesting because the IAC made some recommendations as to how government money or support should be provided which did not meet with the approval of quite a few people who thought they were free traders in relation to manufacturing and primary industries and were always demanding that we should follow the IAC reports. When this report hit the deck they were so upset that they said that there should not be a final government decision because the whole thing was unacceptable to them. It is marvellous how principles can be very flexible with some people.

As to the Multilateral Trade Negotiations and the European Economic Community, the EEC basically said that it would provide greater access for a variety of meat products. Australia was shut out of the European market for cheese when Great Britain joined the EEC in 1972-73 but heavily subsidised EEC cheese was allowed untrammelled entry into Australia at that time following Senator Murphy's removal of the anti-dumping provisions against European cheese which were in force when the Labor Government took office. The EEC was allowed to increase rapidly its penetration of the cheese market in Australia at a time when we were not allowed access to the European market. The MTN arrangement was that 3,000 tonnes of Australian cheese could be imported into Europe and in return we would guarantee the entry of duty free cheese into Australia provided there was no export subsidy from Europe-I can assure the House that the export subsidy is only one of quite a range of subsidies that come into their support system-and also the current duty rate of $96 per tonne for certain types of cheese at fairly generous tonnage rates. Other arrangements were made for some other products. For example, with canned pears it was stated that there could be no reduction from 24 per cent in the common external tariff, but there was a promise that nothing else would be done concerning access to that market for Australian canned pears. Within six months the EEC introduced a subsidy to encourage the canning of pears in Europe at a value which was twice that which Australian canned pear producers received. In other words, it was the equivalent of a dramatic increase in the tariff against canned pears going into Europe. The EEC tried to renege on the MTN arrangement on increased access for Australian beef. Hence the threats and demands that were made by the Australian Government.

What I am saying is that when we are dealing with the EEC we are dealing with people whose word cannot be trusted, who are tough operators, and who do not hesitate to subsidise and double subsidise. I believe that we have been very generous in relation to cheese to the EEC. There are other countries which highly subsidise their cheese exports to this country and which do not belong to the EEC. Australian producers of cheese will suffer because the IAC recommendation of a $200 per tonne tariff or bounty for cheese was not accepted. The tariff or bounty will remain at $96 per tonne. I am referring to Norway, Austria and so on. The Government's decision on access for New Zealand cheese was a rejection of the specific IAC recommendation of a $200 per tonne tariff or bounty. The Government's announcement, which I have already quoted, was that it should be one or the other, depending on whether cheese remained on Schedule A. I wish to quote from the media release of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) concerning the Government's attitude to New Zealand cheese. The Press release stated:

It was also announced that a decision on the question of assistance to the Australian cheese industry would be deferred to enable consultations to take place between Australian and New Zealand industry representatives and Ministers regarding New Zealand's cheese marketing objectives in Australia.

As a result of those consultations agreement between the N.Z. Board (NZDB) and the Australian industry was reached in August 1980 to establish a Joint Dairy Industry Consultative Committee and the NZDB undertook to limit its exports of cheese to Australia in 1980 to the same level recorded in 1979. The Industry Consultative Committee held its first meeting in December 1980 and is expected to meet again in May this year-
That is, 1981-
with a view to agreeing on the level of exports by the NZDP to Australia in 1981.

I now wish to quote from the response of Mr John Bennett, the President of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, to the Government's decision. In relation to the IAC, Mr Bennett is reported to have said:
. . . 'the greatest waste of time I have ever been associated with.'
'The Government seems to be practising a double standard when dealing with IAC reports on rural and non rural industries'.

'Within the manufacturing sector, the IAC is criticised for being too harsh in its recommendations for restructuring heavily protected industries. By contrast, the cheese industry which receives very little Government assistance, has the unique distinction, as the only industry where tariff assistance had been reduced by the Government following an IAC recommendation for higher tariff levels'.

In conclusion, I wish to make a couple of further points. First of all, New Zealand and the EEC have been very well treated. They have been treated in a fairer manner than they deserve. I have already given some details regarding the EEC. A case of illegal dumping of cheese in this country was proved against New Zealand but, by the skilful use of the special provisions of NAFTA, the New Zealand industry and Government were able to prolong and postpone the final decision on New Zealand cheese coming to this country, during which time New Zealand dramatically increased the amount of cheese coming in, so it had a higher base from which to negotiate when the final decision was reached. That decision was reached and, incidentally, has been working quite well. No sooner had the argument between Australia and New Zealand on access for cheese been settled, following the IAC inquiry, than the New Zealand Prime Minister, in what I consider was a very one-sided proposal for expanded Australia-New Zealand trade, demanded more concessions of the Australian dairying industry. The New Zealand dairying industry is far more heavily subsidised than the Australian industry. In fact the Australian dairying industry is the least subsidised of any dairying industry in the Western World. Our dairying industry stood aside and did not argue against the special provisions or access for the New Zealand dairying industry, which has helped the industry dramatically in the returns to its producers and has allowed it to avoid the restructuring hell that our dairying industry had to go through, when the Australian Government's decision was for less than the IAC had recommended for protection against New Zealand cheese.

I was very pleased with the Cabinet decision taken by the Australian Government earlier this year in relation to closer economic relations with New Zealand. I believe from the published reports that I have read that the attitude is far more balanced. It stated that genuine two-way trade has to be negotiated, that all industries have to be involved. Basically the arrangements agreed to following the IAC report on cheese and the proving of the dumping of cheese against New Zealand must stand. I emphasise the point that this Government must stick to that position in its negotiations with New Zealand for closer economic relations. Any further concession at the expense of the Australian dairying industry would be grossly unfair to an industry which, unlike the manufacturing industry, has been granted far less protection than that recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some respects the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has made a very good speech in support of the amendment. He argued that we ought to be much more aware of decisions that are made in relation to particular industries and that decisions need to be based on a full recognition of all the factors involved, not on narrow grounds. Whilst I am not in any sense trying to draw a dichotomy between the rural and manufacturing sector, I want to concentrate my remarks in relation to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill around the question of industry policy. In some respects what I will say is complementary to the remarks made by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford).

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill, in referring to levels of protection in a wide range of industries, for example, within the manufacturing sector, provides an opportunity to discuss the issues of protection and industry policy within Australia. I want to refer in particular to the situation in the manufacturing industry. The sharp decline that occurred during the 1970s-a decline which to some extent has been arrested but not reversed-has placed in question the future of manufacturing industry in Australia. Undoubtedly, there is a possibility that if present policies are continued, within a period Australia will cease to be a country with a strong manufacturing base. The Opposition has consistently supported manufacturing industry essential to the health of the Australian economy. It is crucially important to Australia's independence and security.

The House does not need to be reminded that the decision to expand the manufacturing industry in Australia was integral to the Chifley White Paper on full employment published in 1945 and the approach taken by that Government to post-war reconstruction. During the war it was recognised that Australia not only had the human resources but also the natural resources necessary to become a strong manufacturing country. The government of the time sought to provide the framework for that growth to take place. The principal emphasis of the Chifley Government with respect to manufacturing industry was followed by successive governments until, I believe, the advent of the Fraser Government. However, there was no doubt that by the middle 1960s the Australian manufacturing industry was moving into a situation of crisis-a deep malaise which was the burden of the Jackson report on manufacturing industry commissioned by the Whitlam Government. The reasons for the malaise which affected the manufacturing industry are certainly not simple. They are complex and relate to a range of government policies, the parlous state of management within Australia, as well as to new strategies being adopted by international capital.

I believe the most important reason for the decline of manufacturing industry was the decision taken during the late 1960s for international capital to begin to restructure its international operations away from the emphasis that had been placed on securing industrial bases and access to markets within countries such as Australia which operated policies on an import replacement basis. During the post-war period the Australian Government accepted substantial foreign investment in return for the development of manufacturing industry, such as vehicles and chemicals, on the understanding that some of these industries would require protection, but that they would contribute to the development in Australia of what I would describe as an independent industrial base. I stress that the reason for the develoment of this industry was primarily for political and not economic reasons.

Over the past decade we have seen a movement of international capital towards strategies which are designed not to concentrate industry in particular countries but to seek maximum diversification, the achievement of greater economies of scale by the breaking up of the final product into component parts which may be made in different parts of the world and, in particular, the concentration of labour-intensive production in Third World countries which have cheap labour readily available. Often these countries have not only that characteristic but also they often have an absence of any free trade union structure, repressive labour laws, and a number of government incentives to capital not available in Western countries. Restructuring of capital has now reached a stage where Australian manufacturers are competing with multinational companies, often Western owned or based, operating in low wage countries with Western capital and technology and substantial incentives from the host governments. The reality of the matter is that it is impossible for Australia to compete with these corporations without achieving substantial reductions in living standards.

A central thrust to the Crawford report was that the Australian economy should be restructured to allow for the development of that economy around highly capital intensive resource-based industries and also high technology industries. Australia's secondary industry would be fined down with a principal emphasis on the manufacture in Australia of only separate parts of total production, such as cars and those parts manufactured under complementation schemes which are highly capital and energy intensive. It has been argued by a number of honourable members on the Government side that Australia needs to pay less attention to protecting Australian industry and more attention to developing new industries in line with the kinds of industries described in my reference to the Crawford report. It has been argued that we need to accept the trends occurring in the international economy, adopt more outward looking strategies, and accept the fact that national interest ought to play a secondary role in relation to economic policy. It has been argued at international forums that Australia is committed to reducing protectionism at least in the longer term and that it is prepared to accept a role for itself which would increasingly stress its primary produce, minerals and mineral processing industries. A reduced role for manufacturing would be accepted as Australia would be forced to import more and more manufactured goods for balance of trade reasons.

I wish to refer briefly to some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Murray where he tended to set the interests of rural industry against the interests of the manufacturing industry. I am well aware that often that has been a characteristic of debate within this Parliament. But I think one ought to recognise that whilst the contribution of rural industry is extremely important in terms of creating the wealth of this country, the reality is that in the post-war period we deliberately pursued a strategy of developing a manufacturing industry which has come to be a very large employer indeed. Whilst there may be problems in terms of particular sections of industry-I certainly do not want to deny that there are very serious problems in the way in which Australian secondary industry is structured-the reality is that the protection of living standards and the survival of a very high proportion of the Australian population actually employed or dependent upon people employed in the manufacturing industry, makes that subject extremely important in a very direct sense. I do not want to compare those two matters but I think one has to understand when one is talking about manufacturing industry, that on many occasions people whose interests are perhaps more identified with the rural sector have spoken out very strongly about the protection that has been developed for manufacturing industry in Australia. In defence of that I would have to argue that Australia has deliberately gone ahead and developed a policy which I believe the Government is seeking to desert.

I have already made some reference to the international restructuring that is taking place. I suggest that if this restructuring continues there almost certainly will be an inevitable reduction in effective rates of protection within Australia. For example, it has been estimated that over the past year or so a revaluation of currency has occurred which has resulted in a reduction of 8 per cent in the effective rate of protection. Further, a revaluation of the order of 10 per cent could result in wiping out all protection for half of all manufacturing industry. It is true also that as a result of the restructuring which is occurring we are seeing more and more of the goods which are imported specifically related to the needs of the so-called resource-based industries. It has been estimated that as much as half of our current imports are for capital goods and transport equipment which are directly or indirectly related to resource-based industries.

Often the assumption has been made that by reducing the effective levels of protection one effectively reduces prices. That assumption, of course, is a naive one. The reality is that prices are increasingly being determined in a way which reflects the power of producers operating in a monopoly situation or, at least, in an oligopoly situation. As the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) is at the table, I mention again the example-not that I think it is particularly relevant to the issue of protection-that I mentioned yesterday during Question Time in relation to aluminium prices. The Minister has made some noises about market forces. The reality is that the price of aluminium ingot in Australia for each of the three major producers is exactly the same-$1,545 a tonne. When that price changes it changes at almost exactly the same time for each of the three producers. From the point of view of the manufacturers who are purchasing that ingot, they are completely certain that they are not operating in a free market. The price is, in turn, based on a producer price on the Hong Kong-Alcan producer price. It is a price which has not been particularly sensitive to movement. Other producer prices have seen and, of course, the spot price markets have seen dramatic changes. Those changes, being downward in terms of international prices, have not been reflected in Australian aluminium ingot prices at all. If anything, the Australian price might be regarded as having gone up in relation to the Hong Kong-Alcan producer price rather than having gone down.

We are increasingly in a situation where prices are not determined by market forces. They are determined by a few producers who control a particular product. We know that the most dominant industries within the Australian economy are, in fact, those industries in which there is the greatest concentration of economic power, the greatest degree of oligopoly. To suggest that if one removes protection somehow one is about to create a situation where prices will move downwards is to ignore the fact that we have within this country very imperfect economic competition and that price is, in fact, much more determined by the cost structure of the producers and by the goals of producers than it is by any market forces. So the assumption that, if we somehow reduce levels of protection and expose the Australian economy to international forces, somehow we will get a miraculous reduction in prices and consumers will get the benefits of the gains that might be achieved, is, I believe, very doubtful.

I think it is important to stress that, at a time in which many honourable members in the Government are increasingly talking in more enthusiastic ways about so-called market forces, what they are talking about is essentially what they would like to be the case rather than what the contemporary economic reality might be. Now, if that is true in terms of the domestic Australian economy, of course, it is also true internationally. When we talk about what is happening in terms of the international economy, particularly what is happening in terms of the countries that might export to Australia, we are not talking about a situation in ASEAN where there is necessarily massive competition everywhere. We are talking about developing economies even within the Third World where the development that occurs very often occurs within large transnational corporations operating perhaps through subsidiaries and very often trading with themselves. One can imagine that the more the Australian economy becomes open, for example, to the ASEAN economy, the more we are simply going to have transnational companies being able to export into Australia certainly taking advantage of perhaps cheaper inputs within those countries but not necessarily operating within an internationally competitive market. I think it is extremely important to stress that point. There is a great deal of mythology about competition. It has been a strong ideology within the Liberal Party historically. The reality is that there is not a great deal of competition within the economic world today; there is increasingly less competition.

I referred to the fact that in recent weeks debate in this House has tended to sharpen somewhat. It has been made quite clear that the two sides of the House have been talking about two things-commitment to a free market economy and commitment to a planned economy. Continuing protection, where it is provided by this Government, in my view represents, as the honourable member for Adelaide pointed out, nothing more or less than sophisticated political opportunism. It is not part of any long term strategy to build an effective industrial base for the Australian economy.

The Opposition on the other hand wants to talk about planning and about a planned economy. The rejection of the Liberals of planning in the post-War period has been one of the greatest disasters of modern Australian industry. The reality is that modern capitalism is dependent now for its survival on the support of the State. There is no doubt that modern industry is dependent on subsidies. The logical outcome of free trade market orientated policies would be the destruction of the capitalist system. There is even an argument here for socialists to support the Industries Assistance Commission approach because that would hasten the demise of capitalism. On the other hand, the suffering caused by Friedmanism would be enormous and no socialist could ask his people to bear that suffering if it could be avoided. The solution is a planned economy.

Australia is the only country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which has no commitment to overall planning. We are not talking about socialists on the one hand and free market economies on the other. Almost every country in the OECD-many of them are mixed economies-is committed to planning. Conservative governments repeatedly throughout the post-War period have rejected the concept of planning. That is absurd. What would a planned economy be within the context of this debate? We need to start with some view, as the honourable member for Adelaide suggested, of what the overall profile of Australian industry should be. Clearly, that profile needs to be based on a number of factors and not simply on narrow concepts of economic efficiency. We need to look, for example, at the overall effects of the development of a particular industry not merely in terms of profits. We have to look at the costs and benefits and to whom they would go with respect to particular industries. We have to look at industry not only in terms of its aggregate effects but also in terms of the economy and particular regions-something that the IAC was never very good at. The IAC, indeed, appears to have been quite insensitive to the social component of industry planning.

We need, I believe, to have some kind of selected industry or leading industry strategy. Not all industries will be equally important. Some industries are more important than others for various reasons. These reasons need to be spelt out and need to be debated. It is unfortunate that some of these issues opened up by the Jackson report have not really been pursued. Quotas and tariff protection should not be handed out as a licence to print money. Support ought to be given in return for specific commitments. There ought to be commitments to maintain levels of employment in an industry. There ought to be agreements about the type of investment powers to be pursued which involve consultation with the workers involved. I believe that there is a lot to be said, as Jackson suggested, for the establishment of effective industry planning councils which are not merely advisory but which might replace the IAC as a planning body. They might be able to enforce agreements with respect to the way that industry should be developed. The investment of public money in industry in my view ought to be accompanied by public equity. There is no doubt that the Australian industry is still uncertain about its future and that large sections of it will wither on the vine, more or less, independently of levels of protection.

The answer to this situation, in my view, is to introduce into industry a much greater degree of planning than currently exists. I fully support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Adelaide. There is no doubt in my mind that this Parliament needs to be more involved in industry planning. Let the members of the back bench economics committee say what they will but ultimately, I believe, there is more chance of decisions being made democratically if we can establish a planning basis in this country than if those decisions were made within the market situation. Finally, the President of France, Premier Mitterrand, won a great victory against the forces of free market economics. The French people were not required to wear the continuing divisions and inequities of free market economics. That Government has placed the strongest commitment to planning. We need a similar commitment in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to some of the comments made in the debate so far. It has been an interesting debate, particularly the speech made by the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe). I recall his dedication to socialist objectives but I think this afternoon we heard a splendid rendition of how a left wing Labor Government would govern Australia. It would set out to create a planned economy. It would not talk about a mixed economy but would go straight for planned economy in which it would make all sorts of decisions relative to industry in Australia. Those sorts of criteria were not spelt out and we do not know exactly what the planning would be aimed at.

SPEECH.PARA: From what he said, one can only assume that the planning would be aimed at worker control, which is one of the terms he threw around quite readily. He did not say anything about labour planning. He did not say anything about the direction of capital, which was implied. He did not say anything about the nationalisation of industry in Australia. He did not say anything about the direction or the limitation of profits and he did not say anything about the limitations or, shall we say, capital tax or capital control. But a planned economy was very much what he was talking about.

On top of that, we ought to look at one or two of the great renditions of the planned economy. I do not leave aside the socialist states, or those states which claim to be socialists but do not really practice what they preach, but let me look at those which act in a democratic sense that we have preferred to those in the great socialist experiment in Great Britain. There we have a magnificent array of industry planning. British Steel was a great contribution to the economy of Britain! Britain now loses a billion dollars a year. What a great contribution! I shall move on to British Leyland, once a mighty car firm, subject to government planning, now it is in ruins.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah, come on. It was in ruins well before it was taken over by the Government. Don't be a liar.
—Order!
—Well, I think that is not a bad comment. I do not mind the honourable member saying those things. But then socialists are not too good at keeping--

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think it is quite unfair for the Minister deliberately to misinterpret and to misrepresent my remarks to this Parliament. I am quite happy to debate with him, but I think we ought to do it on the basis of a bit of honesty.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call the Minister.

—I was referring to the problems associated with socialist governments interfering in the market-place. I was also referring to the disasters of British Steel and British Leyland. I will now refer to one other great effort that the British Government decided to make-the British Food Corporation which came to Australia. The policy was: Let's spread the goodwill! So it came here and established a significant State-owned show in Queensland.
—To grow peanuts.

—To grow all sorts of things. What is left of that Corporation today? Not even a grunt! All those corporations have gone. What a great contribution to planned economy! I will leave that aspect now although it is enlightening to hear the left wing in action.
—Get on to cheese.

—Actually I was going to refer to the speech made by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). The honourable member for Batman has read my thoughts. I can only say in that respect that he is a member who does an enormous amount of work and knows his subject thoroughly. However, I have to defend the Industries Assistance Commission as I think honourable members will expect me to. I think the IAC in Australia is an integral part of economic policy. It certainly goes out, I hope, as an independent force to give its views, sometimes very hurtful to government and sometimes abrasing to individual members with individual interests. I hope that the IAC maintains its economic integrity and, without fear, comes forward with propositions or views on the economy which ought to be debated or drawn to the nation's attention. We are not saying that the Commission is always right, but it should be there. It serves a great part in the economy and makes a great contribution to the Government's economic stance.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), who moved the amendment, spent some time talking about the need for greater care and attention to detail and a number of other matters. These included the proposition that a change of government would in his view bring about greater long term planning and those sorts of things. In the course of his dissertation, he said that I was somewhat negligent for not bringing this Bill on before, that all these Acts have to be amended each six months to validate the proposals. Now that shows great care and attention to detail! As he said, the difficulty is that the proposals were brought in on 2 December. He says that we are now past 2 May; therefore we have passed the six months. That is how good his attention to detail is. Six months would take us to 2 June, so when the honourable member pays attention to detail in the future he might pay it to that particular matter.
