QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the National Parks Service in the United States of America has banned the use of the chemical 2,4-D; if so, is he able to say what were the reasons for this ban.
(2) What quantities of this chemical were (a) imported into and (b) manufactured in Australia in each of the last 5 years.
(3) Which companies manufactured 2,4-D in (a) the United States of America and (b) Australia.
(4) What evaluations from the point of view of potential impact on human health have been carried out of this toxic chemical in Australia.
(5) Are there currently any restrictions on the use of 2,4-D in any Australian State or Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the policy of the United States Department of Interior (USDI) is to maintain national parks in as natural a state as possible and that, wherever practicable, attempts are made to correct problems using natural and biological means before resorting to use of chemicals. The USDI accepts compounds approved by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and does not specifically exclude additional compounds. However, when it is intended that a chemical programme be carried out in a national park, full details must be submitted to the USDI for approval. Approval is based on the type of problem and the relative cost efficiency of natural controls as compared to chemical treatment.
I am further advised that reports from the U.S.A. that the USDI was to halt use of 2,4-D in national parks may have resulted from a misconstrual of the policy outlined above.

(2) (a) Imports of 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid and its salts and esters, which I am advised constitute the technical grade material used in the formulation of herbicides containing 2,4-D, are classified under Item 29.16.200 of the Australian Customs Tariff. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In his capacity as Chairman of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions reviewing Commonwealth departmental staff ceilings, has account been taken of the recommendation of the Departments of Labour Advisory Committee (DOLAC) Working Party regarding the desirability of dissociating Government-employed apprentices from staff cutback and policies of attrition; if so, what.
(2) Will Government employed and trained apprentices be excluded from these policies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Consideration by the Government of the recommendations of the DOLAC Working Party took place before the Committee on Review of Commonwealth Functions was established.
A decision was taken by the Government during the latter half of 1980 which has changed the method of counting apprentices for staff ceilings purposes.
Under the new arrangements separate ceilings are determined for apprentices and the apprentice ceiling cannot be used for other types of staff.

The Government has directed departments and authorities to recruit enough apprentices to ensure that they are self-sufficient in relation to apprentice training; that is, they recruit as many apprentices as are required to maintain expected levels of tradesmen. This direction gave effect to the relevant recommendation of the DOLAC Working Party.

The total apprentice intake approved by the Government for 1981, in the Commonwealth area suubject to ceilings, including apprentices trained under the Group One Year Apprentice Scheme, is the highest level recorded in any one year for the Commonwealth Service.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cocoa Research Project at Nu'u, Western Samoa

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made on the cocoa research project at Nu'u, Western Samoa?
(2) What sum has been spent by Australia on this project since commencement, and what have been the major items of expenditure?

(3) Where larger purchases of materials, buildings, plant and fittings have had to be imported into Western Samoa, have they come from Australian suppliers; if not, from where have they come and why have they come from that source?
(4) What changes of Australian staff have taken place over the last 2 years?

(5) What are the names of relatives of the Australian project manager, Mr K. Newton, or his wife, who have been engaged on the project either on a wages or contract basis and what sum has been paid to each?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cocoa research station at Nu'u is a Western Samoa Government project designed by the Western Samoa Government and based on a report prepared by a cocoa expert. It is partially funded under Austraian aid: funds are provided in the form of an accountable cash grant for the establishment of the station and a staffing assistance grant supplementing local salaries to enable the Western Samoa Government to employ qualified Australians to staff the station.

Establishment of the Australian funded components of the infrastructure for the station is nearly completed. This includes clearing of land and preparation of the site, supply and erection of four prefabricated houses, prefabricated office/laboratory, nursery/propagator building and machinery shed/workshop, planting of 13 acres of shade trees, importation of new types of breeding seed, propagation and planting out of new plants for seed production and the establishment of shade and fertilizer trials at various sites outside the station.
(2) Under the accountable cash grant, $510,000 has been spent on the establishment of the station and an amount of $45,000 through the staffing assistance grant.

Major items of expenditure of Australian funds have been four kit homes, prefabricated office and laboratory, two vehicles, propagator, processing unit and local costs associated with site works and erection of buildings at the station.

(3) Under the terms and conditions for the administration of accountable cash grants, any goods or supplies not locally produced, must be purchased in Australia. An amount of $A13,170 for furniture purchased in New Zealand was not reimbursed from Australian aid funds.

(4) Two Australians were employed by the Western Samoa Government under the Staffing Assistance Scheme to fill the positions of cocoa agronomist who is in charge of the station and a cocoa development officer at the research station and they took up their positions in November 1978 and February 1979 respectively. The cocoa development officer resigned his position in September 1980 and a replacement is currently being recruited by the Western Samoa Government.

(5) As the Western Samoa Government is responsible for the management and operation of the cocoa research station, employment of local, contract or casual labour to work on the station is their responsibility.
Details have been sought from the Western Samoa Government and will be provided in a supplementary answer.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australia-China Council: Media and Information Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government spent $107,857.58 on a media and information program for the Australia-China Council in one year; if so, was any project aimed at exchange of political views or promotion of mutual understanding of political differences between Australia and China.

(2) Is part of the function of the Council to recommend to him the means of promoting greater awareness within each country of the other country and development of public information and assistance to Australian media and research on matters of direct importance to relations between the 2 countries.

(3) Have members of the Council been chosen or suggestions or directions to the Council determined that the most important relationship between the countries, as expressed in ministerial statements, namely strategic relationships, should not be noticed by the Council.
(4) Will the Government set up a similar Council to clarify relationships between Australia and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
(5) Has the Government spent amounts comparable to that referred to in part (1) to encourage exchange of mass media coverage of opposing views in Australia and the U.S.S.R.; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As recorded in the Annual Report of the Australia-China Council for 1979-80, $107,857.58 was spent on the media and information program of the Council. Principal projects funded under this heading which contributed to an exchange of political views or promotion of mutual understanding of political differences between Australia and China included:

The visit to Australia by a delegation of six Chinese journalists led by the Deputy Chief Editor of the People's Daily, and a second visit by a group of five journalists from the proposed English-language paper to be published by the People's Daily. Several major book gifts to the Beijing National Library and the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences purchased in this year have provided reference material on Australia, including Australian political and strategic thinking.

In 1980-81 these programs have continued. At present a joint press seminar is being organised in Beijing through the Australia-China Council and the Chinese Journalists Association, to discuss the background to reporting of each country on the media of the other.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Council has been established, as stated in the order in Council, to promote greater awareness in each country of the other and the enlargement of the areas of contact and exchange between Australia and China. The appointment of members does not relate to any consideration of strategic issues. No suggestions or directions in relation to strategic matters have been given to the Council.
(5) No. Such activities are precluded by the measures imposed by the Government against the Soviet Union following that country's invasion and occupation of Afghanistan.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What stage has been reached as a result of Australian diplomatic representations to the United Soviet Socialist Republic Ministry of Foreign Affairs concerning Ukrainian prisoner of conscience Yuri Shukhevych.
(2) Can he say whether Mr Shukhevych is in his 30th year of imprisonment.
(3) Is he able to say whether Mr Shukhevych's aunt, Mrs S. Strokon of Sydney, had her sponsorship of Yuri as an immigrant approved in 1980 by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(4) Will the release of Yuri Shukhevych, and his migration to Australia, contribute to success in the mutal adherence to the Helsinki Final Accords.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Embassy in Moscow has made representations to the Soviet authorities on behalf of Mr Shukhevych. The Soviet authorities have advised the Embassy that Mr Shukhevych cannot apply to emigrate until he has completed his prison sentence.

(2) Mr Shukhevych is due to complete a ten year prison sentence in March 1982. He is then due to serve a five year period of internal exile. I understand that Mr Shukhevych served terms of imprisonment from 1948 to 1958 and from 1959 to 1969. From 1969 until his imprisonment in 1972 Mr Shukhevych was in internal exile.

(3) My colleague, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, has agreed that Mr Shukhevych and his family will be permitted to emigrate to Australia if the Soviet authorities allow them to leave the Soviet Union. I understand that Mrs Strokon, who is a relation of Mr Shukhevych, is prepared to act as sponsor in this case.

(4) Yes. Australia is not a party to the Helsinki Final Accords. Nevertheless we have in this case and others expressed our abhorrence of the denial of fundamental civil and political rights as officially practised in many parts of the world. The Government has conveyed these views officially to the Soviet authorities on many occasions and has called on them to abide by the human rights principles embodied in United Nations instruments and the 1975 Helsinki Final Accords.
